title: 3D Artist - Career Exploration
description: Experience the 3D Artist career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Creative & Media

questions.question_text: You are a 3D Artist working on a game project with a team of animators and developers. During a team standup meeting, one of the animators shares feedback about your 3D model, suggesting it lacks realism in its texture mapping. You feel the feedback is overly critical and disagree with their perspective. What do you do?

options.text: Request a one-on-one discussion with the animator to understand their feedback and improve the model accordingly.
Dismiss their feedback entirely, believing your work meets the project standards.
Ask the team lead to intervene and mediate the disagreement immediately.
Respond defensively during the meeting and argue your point in front of the team.

questions.question_text: You are a 3D Artist collaborating remotely with a game design team. A colleague requests your help with an urgent texturing task while you're already behind on your own modeling deadline. What do you do?

options.text: Discuss their needs and negotiate a timeline for help while prioritizing your own deadline.
Agree to help immediately and put your own project on hold.
Refuse to help and focus completely on your own work.
Help briefly but do not inform your project manager about the delay caused to your task.

questions.question_text: You are a 3D Artist tasked with creating a realistic environment for a new game level. However, in the gameplay prototype, the lighting and textures you applied look unnatural and ruin the intended atmosphere. What do you do?

options.text: Review the lighting and texture in the prototype, identify the issues, and adjust the assets to better match the setting.
Leave the textures as they are and hope the players won't notice the issues.
Create entirely new assets from scratch without consulting the team to save time.
Ignore the prototype and continue working on other assigned tasks.

questions.question_text: You are using 3D modeling software to develop detailed character designs for a fantasy game. Midway through the project, your software starts crashing repeatedly, slowing your progress. What do you do?

options.text: Troubleshoot the software and update it to the latest version while notifying your team about potential delays.
Continue using the buggy software, hoping the crashes won't disrupt your final submission too much.
Switch to a less advanced software that you're unfamiliar with to avoid further crashes.
Wait until your manager instructs you on what to do, without taking any action.

questions.question_text: You are a 3D Artist reviewing the budget for outsourcing some character animation work. You realize that the cost for outsourcing exceeds the budget allocated for the game project. What do you do?

options.text: Propose alternative solutions to the team, such as handling the animations in-house or negotiating lower quotes.
Ignore the budget issue and proceed with outsourcing since the deadline is tight.
Request additional funds from the project manager to cover the cost without suggesting alternatives.
Cancel the animation tasks entirely to save money, even if it reduces game quality.

questions.question_text: As a 3D Artist, you are asked to estimate the cost of creating a high-quality character model for a client. The client has requested multiple revisions but has a limited budget. What do you do?

options.text: Provide a detailed cost estimate that includes revision fees and deliverables, while suggesting ways to optimize costs.
Agree to complete the work at the client’s budget without considering the complexity of the revisions.
Set an unrealistic price to ensure you can cover all possible revisions.
Ask the client to increase their budget and refuse to proceed unless they comply.

questions.question_text: You are a 3D Artist working under a tight deadline to deliver assets for a game level. The team has asked for progress updates, but your workflow feels inefficient, and you're falling behind. What do you do?

options.text: Reevaluate your workflow, break tasks into manageable chunks, and create a timeline for completion while updating the team.
Continue working without adjusting your workflow or communicating your delays.
Spend extra hours working overtime without informing your team about the challenges.
Delegate your task to another team member without asking for their consent.

questions.question_text: You are a 3D Artist creating a series of models for a sci-fi game. Midway through the project, the creative director changes the art style, requiring adjustments to all existing models. How do you approach this sudden change?

options.text: Communicate with the team to set a revised schedule and prioritize updates to the models based on the new style.
Refuse to adapt your models and continue working on the original style.
Rush through the updates without checking the quality to meet the deadline.
Ask the creative director to revert to the original style and delay the project timeline.

questions.question_text: You are a 3D Artist attending a gaming conference and meet a well-known studio executive. They express interest in your portfolio and ask if you would collaborate on their next big project. How do you respond?

options.text: Share your contact details, express your interest, and follow up with them after the conference.
Respond vaguely and fail to provide concrete details about your work.
Turn down the opportunity, feeling unprepared for such a big collaboration.
Ignore their approach and focus on other attendees at the conference.

questions.question_text: You are a 3D Artist trying to grow your career in the gaming industry. A senior colleague offers to connect you with their contacts at a top game studio, but they advise you to refine your portfolio based on industry trends first. What do you do?

options.text: Take their advice, refine your portfolio, and follow up with them to connect you with their contacts.
Ask them to introduce you immediately, hoping your current portfolio will suffice.
Decline their offer and continue working without networking.
Ignore their advice and send your portfolio to the game studio as-is.

questions.question_text: You are a 3D Artist considering an online certification course in advanced animation techniques. It requires a significant financial commitment but could boost your career prospects at top game studios. What do you do?

options.text: Assess your finances, review the course curriculum, and invest if it aligns with your career goals.
Enroll in the course without evaluating your budget or career needs.
Avoid the course, assuming your current skills are sufficient.
Ask your employer to pay for the course without offering any justification.

questions.question_text: You are a 3D Artist offered a freelance project with a high pay rate but tight deadlines that may require overtime and might impact the quality of your work. What do you do?

options.text: Accept the project but negotiate extra time to ensure quality work.
Decline the project, worrying that you can't meet the deadlines.
Take on the project without addressing the tight deadlines.
Ask for additional pay but still commit to meeting the tight deadlines.

title: Accountant - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Accountant career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Business & Finance

questions.question_text: You are an Accountant in the gaming industry and a junior colleague asks for your help in understanding how to reconcile a complicated account. They are struggling but hesitant to ask for further guidance. What do you do?

options.text: Offer to sit down with them and demonstrate how to reconcile the account step-by-step, encouraging them to ask questions.
Provide them with a general guide and let them figure it out on their own.
Tell them to attend a training session instead of helping them directly.
Criticize their lack of understanding and tell them they need to improve.

questions.question_text: You are an Accountant working on a team project to evaluate financial data for a new gaming product launch. A team member has provided incorrect numbers, which you quickly spot. What do you do?

options.text: Approach the team member in private, explain the error politely, and ask them to correct it.
Ignore the mistake and assume someone else will catch it.
Point out the mistake publicly during the team meeting to ensure others are warned.
Correct the mistake yourself without informing the team member.

questions.question_text: You are an Accountant responsible for preparing the financial statements for a newly launched game. The software you normally use is down, and you need to ensure the statements are accurate and submitted on time. What do you do?

options.text: Use manual methods or alternative tools to create the financial statements with the same level of accuracy.
Postpone submitting the financial statements until the software is functional.
Prepare the financial statements but skip cross-referencing to save time.
Ask your manager to reassign the task to someone else since your software is down.

questions.question_text: You are an Accountant tasked with ensuring accurate invoices for a gaming conference. You realize that a new invoicing tool provided by the company is creating errors in the calculations. What do you do?

options.text: Report the issue to the IT team immediately and manually check all invoices for accuracy.
Ignore the errors since they are minor and unlikely to be noticed.
Stop using the tool and refuse to process invoices until the issue is resolved.
Ask your manager for permission to outsource invoicing temporarily.

questions.question_text: You are an Accountant in the gaming industry creating a budget for a new project. You notice that the proposed costs for marketing are higher than industry standards. What do you do?

options.text: Research comparable marketing budgets in the industry and present a revised proposal to the marketing team.
Approve the marketing budget as it is without question.
Reduce the marketing budget arbitrarily without consultation.
Escalate the issue to your manager without trying to resolve it first.

questions.question_text: You are an Accountant reviewing billing for a new gaming subscription service. You discover that the pricing model mistakenly undercharges customers by a small amount. What do you do?

options.text: Notify your manager of the issue and recommend adjusting the pricing model immediately to align with company policies.
Leave the pricing model unchanged since it's only a small discrepancy.
Increase prices across the board to cover the losses without informing anyone.
Ignore the issue and let the marketing team handle it.

questions.question_text: You are an Accountant managing a tight deadline for submitting compliance reports. Midway through, you notice a missing document necessary to complete the report. What do you do?

options.text: Pause your work, request the missing document immediately, and adjust your timeline to ensure compliance.
Submit the report on time without the missing document and hope no one notices.
Skip the report altogether and focus on other tasks.
Ask for an extension but provide no reason for the delay.

questions.question_text: You are an Accountant overseeing monthly reconciliation processes. You notice team members are using inconsistent workflows that lead to errors. What do you do?

options.text: Develop a standardized reconciliation workflow and train all team members on it.
Allow team members to keep using their individual workflows since it’s easier for them.
Assign the reconciliation tasks to someone else to avoid the errors.
Ignore the errors for now and address them next month.

questions.question_text: You are an Accountant at a gaming company attending an industry networking event. A potential client expresses interest in working with your company but wants to know how your team manages its financial transparency. What do you do?

options.text: Explain your company’s financial practices clearly and professionally, highlighting transparency and accountability.
Provide vague answers to avoid disclosing sensitive information.
Refer them to your manager without addressing their question.
Dismiss the question and focus on selling the company’s services.

questions.question_text: You are an Accountant and have been given the opportunity to lead a high-profile financial project for a major gaming launch. However, you are also managing other responsibilities that are taking up most of your time. What do you do?

options.text: Assess your current workload, delegate where possible, and prioritize tasks to make time for this new opportunity.
Decline the opportunity to avoid overextending yourself.
Take on the project but set it aside until you finish your current tasks.
Agree to the project immediately without assessing your workload or capacity.

questions.question_text: You are an Accountant working on a tax report for your gaming company. You notice a potential deduction that could save the company money but might be considered questionable by tax authorities. What do you do?

options.text: Consult with a tax expert or your manager to confirm whether the deduction is legitimate before proceeding.
Include the deduction in the report without verifying its legitimacy.
Avoid using the deduction to stay on the safe side, even if it could benefit the company.
Ignore the issue and submit the report as it is.

questions.question_text: You are an Accountant considering obtaining a specialized certification in gaming finance to help advance your career. However, the certification is costly and will require extra hours of study. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the potential impact of the certification on your career growth and decide to invest in it despite the cost.
Avoid the certification due to the cost and time commitment.
Wait for a company reimbursement program before pursuing the certification.
Decide against the certification, as you feel it may not significantly impact your career.

title: Auditor - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Auditor career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Business & Finance

questions.question_text: You are an Auditor tasked with reviewing financial records at a gaming company that has recently merged with another firm. A junior colleague on your team is unsure how to interpret a critical section of the documentation and asks for guidance. What do you do?

options.text: Explain the section thoroughly to your colleague and ensure they understand how to proceed while encouraging them to ask questions.
Tell your colleague you’re busy and suggest they research the issue independently.
Take over the task entirely without explaining the process to your colleague.
Ignore the colleague's request and focus on your own work.

questions.question_text: You are an Auditor conducting an interview with a department manager about financial controls. During the interview, the manager becomes defensive and refuses to share certain documents you requested. What do you do?

options.text: Calmly explain the importance of the documents for compliance purposes and offer to address any concerns they may have.
Demand the documents immediately and tell them their refusal will be escalated.
Stop the interview and report the issue to your supervisor without further discussion.
Assume they are hiding something and include a note in your audit report without further investigation.

questions.question_text: You are an Auditor reviewing gaming software licensing agreements. You notice that one of the agreements is unclear about renewal terms, which could lead to legal disputes. What do you do?

options.text: Document the ambiguity in your audit findings and recommend consulting a legal expert to clarify and amend the agreement.
Ignore the ambiguity since it hasn’t caused issues so far.
Rewrite the agreement yourself and send it back to the gaming company for approval.
Recommend cancelling the agreement altogether without further investigation.

questions.question_text: You are an Auditor evaluating the company’s use of a new analytics software to monitor gaming revenue. You notice the software occasionally provides incorrect financial projections. What do you do?

options.text: Report the software inaccuracies in your audit findings and recommend an immediate review by the IT department.
Assume the inaccuracies are minor and don’t warrant attention.
Suggest replacing the software without consulting the IT team.
Wait until the inaccuracies cause a major issue before addressing it in the audit.

questions.question_text: You are an Auditor preparing a budget for travel expenses related to an upcoming audit of several client locations. The company has strict policies for managing costs. What do you do?

options.text: Research cost-effective travel and accommodation options that align with company policies and present the budget for approval.
Create a budget with higher-end options as a buffer, just in case more expensive travel is required.
Include only the cheapest options without considering logistics or comfort.
Submit a budget with minimal detail and leave decisions about travel costs to others.

questions.question_text: You are an Auditor reviewing the pricing structure of a gaming company’s subscription model. You find that the current pricing tiers may not be generating optimal revenue. What do you do?

options.text: Recommend an analysis of user data and market trends to determine if adjustments to pricing tiers could improve revenue.
Advise the company to lower all subscription prices to attract more customers regardless of impact on profitability.
Suggest keeping the pricing structure unchanged to avoid complications.
Propose raising all prices without consideration of market conditions.

questions.question_text: You are an Auditor tasked with ensuring compliance with internal audit procedures at a gaming company. You notice a team member is skipping key steps in the process to meet deadlines. What do you do?

options.text: Address the issue directly with the team member, emphasizing the importance of following procedures and compliance standards.
Ignore the skipped steps since they are meeting deadlines.
Report the team member’s actions immediately to your supervisor without speaking to them.
Modify the process yourself without consulting others to make it faster.

questions.question_text: You are an Auditor reviewing audit procedures for a gaming company’s new product launch. The process documentation is outdated and misses crucial steps. What do you do?

options.text: Update the documentation and propose implementing the missing steps to ensure accurate audits for future launches.
Ignore the outdated documentation since the product was launched successfully.
Suggest scrapping the current audit procedures entirely and starting from scratch.
Note the outdated documentation but take no action for now.

questions.question_text: You are an Auditor aiming to grow your career by strengthening relationships with gaming industry clients. During a meeting, a client expresses interest in learning more about how audits can improve operational efficiency. What do you do?

options.text: Offer to provide examples and insights, positioning yourself as a valuable resource for their business.
Suggest they read the audit report themselves and avoid further discussion.
Change the subject and focus solely on compliance topics.
Refer the client to another department instead of addressing their questions.

questions.question_text: You are an Auditor attending a networking event hosted by gaming industry professionals. An executive from a prominent company seems genuinely interested in your expertise. How do you respond?

options.text: Engage in a meaningful conversation about your auditing work and share insights that showcase your knowledge.
Provide a brief overview of your work and quickly move on to another group.
Avoid talking about your expertise and focus on personal topics instead.
Hand them your business card without engaging in conversation.

questions.question_text: You are an Auditor assessing ethical practices in a gaming company’s advertising. You discover that one advertisement may be misleading customers about game features. What do you do?

options.text: Document your findings and recommend the advertisement be revised to ensure ethical compliance.
Assume the advertisement is fine since it hasn’t been reported yet.
Flag the advertisement but take no further action.
Suggest pulling all advertisements as they might have similar issues.

questions.question_text: You are an Auditor considering whether to pursue a professional certification that specializes in gaming industry standards. The certification requires significant time and financial investment. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate how the certification aligns with your long-term career goals and decide based on its potential value.
Sign up for the certification immediately without considering the time and cost.
Ignore the certification and focus on your current role without advancing your skills.
Ask your employer to pay for the certification without considering its benefits.

title: Broadcast Engineer - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Broadcast Engineer career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Broadcast & Production

questions.question_text: You are a Broadcast Engineer managing a live gaming tournament. Midway through the stream, one of your team members reports an issue with a camera feed. The feed is crucial for the audience to see a player's reactions. What do you do?

options.text: Quickly assign another team member to assist in troubleshooting the camera issue while you continue overseeing the broadcast.
Let the team member handle it alone since you're busy monitoring the rest of the stream.
Pause the broadcast immediately to troubleshoot the issue yourself.
Ignore the issue and continue focusing on the stream feed, hoping the problem resolves itself.

questions.question_text: You are a Broadcast Engineer working with a team to prepare for a major esports event. A junior technician is unsure about how to set up the streaming equipment and asks for your guidance. You're on a tight schedule. What do you do?

options.text: Take a few minutes to guide the junior technician through the setup and ensure they understand, so they gain experience.
Tell the junior technician to read the equipment manual and figure it out on their own.
Ignore the technician and continue setting up the equipment yourself to save time.
Have another technician help them, even though they are busy with their own tasks.

questions.question_text: You are a Broadcast Engineer setting up the audio for a gaming livestream. During testing, you notice that the game sound isn't syncing correctly with the video feed, causing a delay. What do you do?

options.text: Adjust the audio delay settings within the broadcasting software to sync the audio with the video.
Turn off the game audio entirely and focus on capturing only the commentators.
Continue with the livestream, assuming the audience won't notice the delay.
Restart the entire setup from scratch since the issue might resolve itself.

questions.question_text: You are a Broadcast Engineer testing gear for a gaming event when you realize one of the wireless microphones is not pairing with its receiver. This microphone is critical for the host. What do you do?

options.text: Check the microphone’s battery and pairing settings, and replace it with a backup if the issue persists.
Ignore the issue since the host can use a different microphone already set up.
Continue troubleshooting the microphone but delay testing the rest of the equipment.
Cancel the use of wireless microphones altogether and use only wired microphones for the event.

questions.question_text: You are a Broadcast Engineer finalizing the budget for a small tournament broadcast. Your client requests the use of top-tier cameras, but this will exceed their allocated budget. What do you do?

options.text: Explain the budget constraints and suggest high-quality but more affordable camera options.
Agree to use the top-tier cameras and exceed the budget, informing the client later.
Agree to use the top-tier cameras and cover the extra cost yourself to win the client's approval.
Cancel the use of cameras altogether to avoid exceeding the budget.

questions.question_text: You are tasked with managing the budget for broadcasting equipment for an esports league season. Your manager requests a report on cost-cutting measures. What do you do?

options.text: Recommend leasing some equipment instead of buying, where possible.
Suggest removing backup equipment to save costs, despite the risks involved.
Cut all non-essential personnel to reduce labor costs without consulting your team.
Insist that the budget is fine as it is and refuse to recommend changes.

questions.question_text: You are a Broadcast Engineer overseeing the livestream workflow for a championship match. An unexpected delay in player arrival disrupts your schedule for setting up equipment. What do you do?

options.text: Adjust the workflow to focus on setting up the most critical equipment first and inform your team of the updated timeline.
Stick to the original schedule regardless of the delay, assuming you can catch up later.
Rush through the setup process to make up for lost time, even if it means cutting corners.
Postpone the entire broadcast until everything is set up perfectly.

questions.question_text: You are managing a live gaming stream. During the event, your control room’s communication system malfunctions, making it hard for you to coordinate with camera operators and on-site staff. What do you do?

options.text: Switch to a backup communication system or use alternative methods like mobile devices.
Wait for the communication system to restart before resuming coordination.
Try to fix the communication system yourself, ignoring the live stream for a few minutes.
Stop the broadcast entirely until the issue is resolved.

questions.question_text: You are a Broadcast Engineer attending a networking event for gaming professionals. A potential client approaches you for advice on upgrading their current streaming setup. What do you do?

options.text: Share some basic advice and offer to set up a consultation to discuss further.
Provide them with a full step-by-step upgrade plan for free right on the spot.
Dismiss their request, as you're attending the event to socialize, not work.
Tell them to look up online tutorials for streaming setup upgrades.

questions.question_text: You recently worked on a successful high-profile gaming livestream. Your manager asks you to present your work to a potential new client to secure a bigger project. What do you do?

options.text: Prepare a concise presentation highlighting the key achievements and technical innovations you implemented.
Send the client a link to the livestream and ask them to review it themselves.
Delegate the presentation to one of your junior technicians.
Decline the request because you don’t feel comfortable presenting.

questions.question_text: You are a Broadcast Engineer considering a professional certification in advanced streaming technology. The certification is expensive but could enhance your skills and career prospects. What do you do?

options.text: Research the certification’s benefits thoroughly and discuss funding options with your employer.
Ignore the certification because of the high cost.
Pay for the certification immediately without researching its relevance to your career.
Wait to pursue the certification until your employer mandates it.

questions.question_text: You are offered a promotion to lead Broadcast Engineer, but it requires moving to another city and managing a larger team. This would significantly advance your career but might disrupt your personal life. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the career benefits and discuss the move with your family before making a decision.
Accept the promotion immediately without considering the impact on your personal life.
Decline the promotion to avoid the challenges of relocation.
Request a delay in accepting the promotion and hope the company agrees.

title: Business Developer - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Business Developer career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Business & Finance

questions.question_text: You are a Business Developer in the gaming industry working on a new partnership deal with a major mobile gaming company. During a video call, a team member from your company unintentionally shares sensitive financial data that wasn't meant for this discussion. The partner company immediately shows interest in the data and starts asking questions. What do you do?

options.text: Politely redirect the conversation back to the intended agenda and schedule a separate meeting to clarify any concerns about the data.
Ignore the partner's interest in the data and continue with the rest of the meeting as planned.
Immediately share more details about the sensitive data to satisfy the partner's curiosity.
End the meeting abruptly and issue an apology to the partner later.

questions.question_text: You are a Business Developer tasked with mentoring a new hire who is struggling to grasp the market analysis tools your team uses. They are hesitant to ask questions during meetings and seem overwhelmed. What do you do?

options.text: Schedule a one-on-one session with the new hire to address their concerns and guide them through the tools step by step.
Tell them to review the company training documents on their own and reach out if they have questions.
Give them additional tasks to encourage them to learn through hands-on experience.
Let them figure things out on their own to build resilience and confidence.

questions.question_text: You are a Business Developer preparing a proposal for a potential partnership with a game development studio. During your research, you identify a feature in their flagship game that could be improved to better align with your company's user base. What do you do?

options.text: Incorporate feedback about the game feature into your proposal and suggest a collaborative plan for improvement.
Avoid mentioning the feature in the proposal to prevent offending the studio.
Highlight the feature as a negative aspect without offering any solutions.
Assume the studio will address the feature issue on their own and focus on other aspects.

questions.question_text: You are a Business Developer working with a team designing a new analytics tool for gaming companies. During the testing phase, you discover the tool is harder to use than competitors' offerings. What do you do?

options.text: Collaborate with the development team to identify areas for improvement in user experience and create a plan to address feedback.
Decide that the user experience is acceptable and proceed with launching the tool as planned.
Delay the tool’s development indefinitely until the user experience matches competitors.
Launch the tool but issue a statement suggesting manual assistance for users who face difficulties.

questions.question_text: You are a Business Developer negotiating pricing terms with a new gaming studio partner. The partner insists on a discount that would reduce your company's profit margin significantly. What do you do?

options.text: Explain your company's pricing structure and offer alternative options that preserve profitability while incentivizing the partnership.
Accept the partner’s request for the discount to ensure the partnership is finalized quickly.
Flatly reject the discount request without further explanation.
Request a higher budget from your company to accommodate the discount.

questions.question_text: You are a Business Developer managing a tight budget for a conference sponsorship opportunity in the gaming sector. One of the sponsorship packages offers better exposure but goes over your budget by 15%. What do you do?

options.text: Negotiate with the conference organizers to see if they can provide additional benefits at a lower cost.
Purchase the more expensive sponsorship package and reduce spending elsewhere in your budget.
Settle for a basic sponsorship package that fits within the budget but offers minimal exposure.
Decline all sponsorship packages and allocate the budget to other opportunities.

questions.question_text: You are a Business Developer tasked with streamlining the proposal creation workflow for your team, which has been struggling with delays. The current process involves too many approval steps, causing bottlenecks. What do you do?

options.text: Redesign the workflow to reduce redundant approval steps and implement software for better collaboration.
Encourage the team to work faster and prioritize deadlines without changing the workflow.
Add more approval steps to ensure higher-quality proposals.
Delay proposal deadlines to give the team more time to work within the existing process.

questions.question_text: You are a Business Developer tasked with managing your weekly schedule across client calls, team meetings, and project deadlines. You realize that some of your client calls overlap with critical internal meetings. What do you do?

options.text: Reschedule the overlapping client calls to ensure you can attend internal meetings without interruptions.
Skip the internal meetings and prioritize client calls, as they directly impact business growth.
Attend the internal meetings and delegate the client calls to a colleague without consulting them.
Handle both tasks simultaneously by joining the meetings and client calls on separate devices.

questions.question_text: You are a Business Developer attending an industry networking event for gaming professionals. A high-profile game developer expresses interest in collaborating with your company but seems hesitant. What do you do?

options.text: Engage them in a detailed conversation about potential collaboration benefits and follow up with a personalized email.
Ask them to consider your company and provide them with a generic brochure about your services.
Wait for them to reach out to you after the event if they’re truly interested.
Immediately commit to any demands they make to secure their interest.

questions.question_text: You are a Business Developer looking to advance your career. A competitor company in the gaming industry offers you a senior position with better pay but less flexibility and no opportunity to travel to industry events. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the long-term impact on your career goals and decline the offer if it doesn't align with your priorities.
Accept the position immediately to secure the higher pay.
Ask your current employer for a raise to match the competitor’s offer.
Accept the competitor's offer but plan to switch back to your current company later for better flexibility.

questions.question_text: You are a Business Developer negotiating a deal with a gaming studio where your company would invest in their next project. During discussions, the studio suggests adding features that would double the budget but only increase potential revenue by 10%. What do you do?

options.text: Advise against adding the features and focus on maximizing ROI by sticking to the original budget.
Agree to the budget increase since it will make the project more innovative.
Suggest abandoning the project entirely to avoid financial risk.
Agree to the additional features but ask for a larger share of the revenue generated.

questions.question_text: You are a Business Developer considering whether to invest your time and resources into earning a certification in advanced sales techniques that could boost your negotiation skills. The course is expensive and requires significant time commitment. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the potential return on investment, and if the certification aligns with your long-term goals, enroll in the course.
Enroll in the course immediately without considering its impact on your current workload or budget.
Ignore the certification opportunity and focus instead on building experience through practice.
Ask your employer to cover the costs without considering the benefits to your career.

title: Cloud Security Engineer - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Cloud Security Engineer career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Technology

questions.question_text: You are a Cloud Security Engineer overseeing a team investigating a potential breach in your company's gaming cloud infrastructure. One of your team members struggles to identify the source of the issue and asks for your help during a meeting. What do you do?

options.text: Guide the team member through troubleshooting steps and ensure everyone understands the process for future incidents.
Take over the task entirely, resolving the issue without involving the team member further.
Delay responding to the team member until the meeting concludes to avoid disrupting the discussion.
Criticize the team member's performance in front of the team to emphasize the importance of competence.

questions.question_text: You are a Cloud Security Engineer collaborating remotely with developers to implement security measures for a new gaming feature. The developers disagree on the security protocols suggested, creating tension in the discussion. What do you do?

options.text: Facilitate a discussion to clarify the security protocols and explain their importance in preventing vulnerabilities.
Let the developers continue their disagreement and focus on your own tasks without intervening.
Immediately escalate the issue to senior management without attempting to mediate first.
Compromise on the protocols by removing some security measures to appease the developers.

questions.question_text: You are a Cloud Security Engineer tasked with auditing the company’s cloud servers. You discover that some gaming data backups are not encrypted, leaving them vulnerable to potential breaches. What do you do?

options.text: Immediately implement encryption protocols for the backups and document the change.
Ignore the issue since no breaches have occurred yet and focus on other tasks.
Notify the development team and rely on them to address the encryption problem.
Delete the vulnerable backups to prevent unauthorized access.

questions.question_text: You are a Cloud Security Engineer and your company is adopting a new tool to monitor gaming server traffic for anomalies. During the trial phase, you notice some critical features are missing. What do you do?

options.text: Report the missing features to the vendor and suggest modifications or alternatives.
Continue using the tool without addressing the missing features since it still works in some areas.
Discontinue the trial immediately and move to a backup tool without notifying stakeholders.
Demand a refund from the vendor without further discussing the issues.

questions.question_text: You are a Cloud Security Engineer and the gaming company plans to expand its cloud infrastructure. Your manager asks you to provide a cost estimate for additional security measures. What do you do?

options.text: Research the costs of scalable security solutions and prepare a detailed, realistic estimate including potential risks.
Provide a rough estimate without thorough research to save time.
Suggest the most expensive solutions to ensure maximum security without considering the budget.
Convince the manager to delay the expansion to reduce costs.

questions.question_text: You are a Cloud Security Engineer responsible for managing the security budget of the company's gaming servers. Due to budget cuts, you must reduce expenses while maintaining high security. What do you do?

options.text: Identify less critical security features to scale back while maintaining core protections for sensitive data.
Cancel all security upgrades and rely solely on existing protections.
Switch to a cheaper service provider without evaluating potential security risks.
Reduce the number of staff handling security to cut costs.

questions.question_text: You are a Cloud Security Engineer implementing new compliance protocols on the gaming cloud infrastructure. A strict deadline has been set by regulatory authorities. What do you do?

options.text: Prioritize tasks based on their impact on compliance and create a schedule to meet the deadline.
Focus on other security updates and delay the compliance tasks if time runs short.
Ignore less critical protocols to meet the deadline faster.
Outsource the implementation to an external consultant without discussing it with your manager.

questions.question_text: You are a Cloud Security Engineer reviewing daily security logs for the company's gaming servers. You detect a spike in suspicious activity but have other urgent tasks lined up. What do you do?

options.text: Immediately prioritize investigating the suspicious activity since it might indicate a potential breach.
Continue with your scheduled tasks and review the logs later.
Mark the activity as a false positive without verification to save time.
Delegate the task to a junior employee without providing additional instructions.

questions.question_text: You are a Cloud Security Engineer hoping to advance your career by showcasing your expertise in securing gaming cloud infrastructure. The company is holding a conference for industry leaders. What do you do?

options.text: Volunteer to present on the company's innovative security measures to build your reputation.
Attend the conference but avoid participating actively to focus on networking quietly.
Skip the conference altogether since it conflicts with your daily work schedule.
Delegate preparation for the conference to another team member.

questions.question_text: You are a Cloud Security Engineer interested in expanding your skillset. A colleague suggests pursuing advanced certification in cloud security practices, but it requires significant time and money. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the ROI of the certification and pursue it if it aligns with your career goals.
Decline the suggestion, as the cost and time outweigh the potential benefits.
Accept the suggestion without considering how it fits into your career path.
Ask your employer to fund the certification without explaining its value.

questions.question_text: You are a Cloud Security Engineer and discover that a senior executive has requested bypassing a critical security protocol to accelerate a new gaming feature’s release. What do you do?

options.text: Explain the risks to the executive and recommend alternative ways to meet the deadline without compromising security.
Agree to bypass the protocol since it was requested by a senior executive.
Comply with the request but document your objection for future reference.
Refuse outright without discussing alternatives or explaining consequences.

questions.question_text: You are a Cloud Security Engineer looking to maximize your long-term value to the company. A costly but highly regarded online course on advanced cloud security architecture is available. What do you do?

options.text: Invest in the course to bolster your skills and provide future value to the company.
Ignore the course since it requires a significant financial investment.
Ask the company to pay for the course without explaining how it benefits them.
Sign up for the course without considering how it fits into your career path.

title: Community Manager - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Community Manager career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Marketing & Community

questions.question_text: You are a Community Manager for a popular online gaming platform. A member of your team sends you a message complaining about another team member who is dismissive of their suggestions during meetings, and tension is building. What do you do?

options.text: Arrange a private meeting with both team members to address the situation and mediate a resolution.
Tell the complaining team member to handle the situation themselves to promote independence.
Ignore the complaint and hope the issue resolves itself over time.
Publicly announce during the next team meeting that everyone needs to respect each other's input.

questions.question_text: You are a Community Manager moderating a large online forum for gamers. One of the forum moderators has been accused by multiple community members of favoritism and unfairly removing posts. What do you do?

options.text: Investigate the complaints, gather evidence, and have a private discussion with the moderator to address any concerns.
Immediately remove the moderator from their role to prevent further issues.
Ignore the accusations, as moderators are trusted members of the team.
Publicly defend the moderator in the forum without investigating the complaints.

questions.question_text: You are a Community Manager, and the development team just released a new gaming update. Players are reporting a bug that causes an important feature to crash. What do you do?

options.text: Immediately inform the development team about the bug and create a post to let the community know that the issue is being addressed.
Tell the players to submit detailed bug reports, but don't alert the development team until more reports come in.
Downplay the issue in the community by claiming that it only affects a few users.
Ask the players to stop using the feature for now without explaining why.

questions.question_text: You are a Community Manager, and your team is brainstorming ideas to improve user engagement in your gaming community. One idea involves using a new platform that none of your team members have used before. What do you do?

options.text: Research the platform thoroughly and organize a training session for your team to ensure they are prepared to use it effectively.
Reject the idea because it will take time to learn the new platform and stick with your current methods.
Approve the idea without any training, trusting that your team will figure it out along the way.
Ask the development team to integrate the new platform into your workflow without consulting your team.

questions.question_text: You are a Community Manager planning a virtual event for your online gaming community. You want to hire a guest speaker, but their fee exceeds your budget. What do you do?

options.text: Negotiate with the guest speaker to see if they can offer a discounted fee or alternative compensation like promotional opportunities.
Cancel the event entirely since you cannot afford the speaker.
Agree to pay the speaker's fee in full and worry about the budget later.
Find a way to cut other expenses without consulting the team to allocate more money for the speaker.

questions.question_text: You are tasked with buying a new analytics tool for community engagement metrics. The tool your team prefers is more expensive than the budget allows. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the features of the preferred tool and find a similar, more affordable tool that meets most of your team's needs.
Purchase the preferred tool and exceed the budget, assuming the benefits are worth it.
Convince your team to go without an analytics tool to save money.
Select the cheapest tool without consulting your team, as it fits the budget.

questions.question_text: You are a Community Manager creating a content calendar for your gaming community. A last-minute update from the development team alters the game's schedule significantly. What do you do?

options.text: Update the content calendar as soon as possible, notifying both your team and the community about the changes.
Leave the calendar as it is and let the development team handle any confusion from the community.
Postpone all community updates until you have more information from the development team.
Announce the new schedule but keep the content calendar unchanged to save time.

questions.question_text: You are managing a weekly newsletter for your gaming community. You realize shortly before the scheduled send-out time that there's a critical error in the newsletter content. What do you do?

options.text: Delay the newsletter, correct the error, and send it out late with an apology for the delay.
Send the newsletter as it is to meet the deadline, hoping no one notices the error.
Cancel the newsletter entirely and wait until next week to send a new one.
Quickly send out a follow-up email correcting the error after the newsletter has been sent.

questions.question_text: You are a Community Manager and just organized a successful virtual gaming event that received positive feedback. A reporter reaches out to you for an interview about your work. What do you do?

options.text: Agree to the interview, highlighting the team's efforts and the community's engagement during the event.
Politely decline the interview, as you're unsure about speaking to the media.
Refer the reporter to someone else in the company without providing any details about the event.
Provide information to the reporter but avoid speaking about the team's contributions.

questions.question_text: A well-known influencer shows interest in promoting your gaming community, which could lead to a large increase in membership. How do you proceed?

options.text: Engage the influencer, discuss collaboration opportunities, and outline clear expectations and deliverables.
Let the influencer promote your community without providing any input or guidance.
Ignore the influencer's interest because you are unsure of their impact.
Request that the influencer only promotes your community in exchange for free membership.

questions.question_text: You notice that some community members are spreading rumors about an upcoming game feature that is not true, and it is causing unrealistic expectations. What do you do?

options.text: Post an official statement as soon as possible to address the rumors and provide accurate information.
Let the rumors continue, as it is generating excitement about the game.
Privately message the members spreading rumors and ask them to stop.
Ask the development team to make changes to match the rumors so the community won't be disappointed.

questions.question_text: You are a Community Manager and notice your team is struggling to meet deadlines due to a lack of proper tools. Purchasing new tools would cut into your department's budget significantly. What do you do?

options.text: Present a business case to your manager, showing how the tools will improve efficiency and deliver higher value in the long term.
Ask your team to work additional hours until the deadlines are met.
Purchase the tools and deal with the budget implications later.
Delay some deliverables to give your team more time without new tools.

title: Content Creator - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Content Creator career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Creative & Media

questions.question_text: You are a Content Creator collaborating with a graphic designer on a new project. The designer sends you artwork that doesn't align with your content's theme. What do you do?

options.text: Respectfully explain the misalignment and provide examples to help the designer understand your vision.
Use the artwork as it is to avoid conflict and meet your deadline.
Criticize the designer’s work without offering constructive feedback.
Scrap the collaboration and complete the design work yourself.

questions.question_text: You are a Content Creator working on a gaming review video. A fan reaches out with critical feedback about how your tone comes across as biased. What do you do?

options.text: Acknowledge the feedback and explain your perspective while thanking them for their input.
Dismiss their feedback and block them from commenting further.
Reply defensively, insisting your review is unbiased without addressing their concerns.
Ignore the feedback completely and continue as planned.

questions.question_text: You’re a Content Creator streaming gameplay footage, but your microphone malfunctions mid-stream, making your voice inaudible. Viewers are commenting about it. What do you do?

options.text: Pause the stream, troubleshoot the microphone issue, and resume once it’s fixed.
Ignore the comments and continue streaming without an explanation.
End the stream abruptly and promise to try again later without addressing the issue.
Apologize to the viewers but continue with the stream, even without audio.

questions.question_text: You are tasked with creating a video walkthrough of a new game. Upon reviewing your final edit, you notice a minor error in one part of the video that might confuse your audience. Fixing it will delay your upload. What do you do?

options.text: Fix the error to ensure your audience receives accurate content and inform them of the slight upload delay.
Upload the video as is since the error is minor and won’t affect most viewers.
Delay the upload indefinitely until the video is absolutely perfect.
Postpone the video and create a completely new one from scratch.

questions.question_text: You’re approached by a small indie game company asking you to create promotional content for their new game. They have a limited budget and offer less than your usual rate. What do you do?

options.text: Negotiate to find a middle ground that works for both you and the company.
Agree to the lower rate without negotiation to maintain a good relationship.
Reject the deal outright and move on to other opportunities.
Ask them to pay your full rate, regardless of their budget constraints.

questions.question_text: You’re planning a gaming tournament stream and need prizes for winners. A sponsor offers funding but suggests cutting costs on prizes to allocate more money to your production quality. What do you do?

options.text: Balance the budget by ensuring both quality prizes and adequate production funding.
Accept the sponsor’s advice and allocate all funding to production, reducing prize quality.
Reject the sponsor entirely and fund the event out of your own pocket.
Focus the budget entirely on prizes, compromising production quality.

questions.question_text: You are a Content Creator with a tight deadline for a new project. Your current workflow involves editing content manually, but you recently learned about software that can automate parts of the editing process. What do you do?

options.text: Take the time to learn the new software, even if it means working extra hours to meet the deadline.
Stick to your manual process since you’re familiar with it and can meet the deadline as is.
Abandon the project entirely until you master the new software.
Hastily use the new software without preparation, risking mistakes in the final product.

questions.question_text: You’re producing daily gaming content, but you notice that staying consistent with uploads is affecting your ability to meet deadlines. What do you do?

options.text: Reorganize your schedule to allow time for both quality content creation and timely uploads.
Reduce your upload schedule to once a week without informing your audience.
Continue pushing daily uploads, sacrificing quality to meet deadlines.
Pause all uploads until you feel ready to restart your daily schedule.

questions.question_text: You’re a Content Creator looking to expand your career. A major gaming convention invites you to host a panel, offering a significant networking opportunity. It conflicts with an existing sponsorship deadline. What do you do?

options.text: Communicate with the sponsor to reschedule the deadline, making time for the convention.
Decline the convention opportunity to prioritize your current sponsorship deadline.
Cancel the sponsorship agreement to attend the convention without delays.
Agree to do both without adjusting deadlines, risking poor delivery for the sponsorship.

questions.question_text: You’re considering launching a new gaming podcast to grow your audience. You’re unsure if your existing followers will support this idea. What do you do?

options.text: Engage your audience with a poll asking if they’d be interested in a gaming podcast.
Launch the podcast immediately without informing your audience.
Abandon the podcast idea entirely to avoid risking audience disappointment.
Create the podcast secretly and only advertise it after it’s released.

questions.question_text: You’re offered two contracts: one involves creating high-quality gaming content with long hours, while the other offers lower-quality work for quick turnaround but higher pay. What do you choose?

options.text: Choose the high-quality content contract to build your reputation and long-term success.
Opt for the higher-paying contract to maximize immediate profits.
Decline both contracts and wait for an ideal opportunity.
Accept both contracts at once, even if it compromises your delivery quality.

questions.question_text: You notice that your current equipment is outdated, and upgrading it could improve your content quality. However, the cost of the upgrade would consume most of your savings. What do you do?

options.text: Invest in the upgrade to enhance your content quality and attract more viewers long-term.
Continue using outdated equipment to save money for future needs.
Take out a loan to fund the upgrade, even if it puts you in financial strain.
Delay the upgrade indefinitely, even if it impacts your content quality.

title: Customer Support - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Customer Support career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Operations & Support

questions.question_text: You are a Customer Support agent at a gaming company. A team member is struggling to resolve a complicated customer issue and seems frustrated. They ask for your help during a busy period. What do you do?

options.text: Offer to assist your team member by taking over the customer issue while encouraging them to take a short break.
Tell your team member to keep trying and focus on your own workload.
Ignore the request because you have your own tasks to complete.
Suggest they hold off on resolving the issue until the team meeting later in the day.

questions.question_text: You are a Customer Support agent. During a team meeting, a colleague consistently interrupts you when you try to share your ideas for improving customer responses. What do you do?

options.text: Politely address the interruptions by saying you’d like to finish your thought before moving on.
Stop contributing to the conversation and remain silent.
Interrupt them back to assert yourself in the meeting.
Raise your concerns about interruptions in a public forum to avoid direct confrontation.

questions.question_text: You are a Customer Support agent for a gaming company. A customer reports a bug in the latest game release, but the software tool used to log issues isn’t working properly. What do you do?

options.text: Manually log the issue in a text document and escalate the problem with the software tool to your manager.
Ask the customer to wait until the tool is fixed before reporting the issue.
Ignore the bug report and focus only on issues that can be logged properly.
Apologize to the customer but do nothing further since the tool isn’t operational.

questions.question_text: You are a Customer Support agent. The company has introduced a new feature in the gaming platform. A customer contacts you to ask for detailed instructions on using the feature, but you haven’t had training on it yet. What do you do?

options.text: Research the new feature using available documentation and guide the customer based on your findings.
Tell the customer they must wait until you receive training before you can assist them.
Advise the customer to contact another support agent instead.
Guess how to use the feature based on your limited knowledge of the platform.

questions.question_text: You are a Customer Support agent. A customer calls, upset about unexpected charges on their account due to an auto-renewal feature they didn’t realize was enabled. What do you do?

options.text: Apologize for the inconvenience, explain the auto-renewal policy, and offer a refund if it falls within company guidelines.
Explain the policy but refuse to offer a refund under any circumstances.
Tell the customer they should have read the terms and conditions before signing up.
Agree to refund the charges immediately without checking company guidelines.

questions.question_text: You are a Customer Support agent. A customer calls and asks for advice on upgrading to a premium subscription to access exclusive features, but they are hesitant due to the extra cost. What do you do?

options.text: Highlight the value and benefits of the premium subscription, and provide them with an overview of the features they’ll gain.
Encourage them to upgrade immediately without explaining the benefits.
Dismiss their concerns about the costs and suggest they subscribe anyway.
Advise them to stick with their current subscription since it’s cheaper.

questions.question_text: You are a Customer Support agent. Your team uses a specific workflow to resolve customer issues, but you notice that one step is inefficient and time-consuming. What do you do?

options.text: Propose an alternative method to your manager that could improve efficiency.
Ignore the inefficiency because the workflow is already established.
Skip the problematic step whenever it slows you down, without informing your manager.
Ask your colleagues to revert to the previous process without consulting management.

questions.question_text: You are a Customer Support agent. A customer contacts you about a time-sensitive issue, but you realize your response time will exceed the standard timeframe outlined in company policy. What do you do?

options.text: Inform the customer of the delay, explain the reason, and assure them you are working on a resolution.
Ignore the issue and prioritize customer inquiries that can be resolved faster.
Apologize but avoid addressing the reason for the delay to avoid further questions.
Escalate the issue to your manager without communicating with the customer.

questions.question_text: You are a Customer Support agent. A regular customer leaves a glowing review for your help on social media and mentions you specifically. Your manager praises you during a team meeting. What do you do?

options.text: Thank the customer publicly on social media and privately thank your manager for the recognition.
Ignore the praise and continue your work as usual.
Ask your manager to give you a reward or bonus for the positive feedback.
Request additional responsibilities to capitalize on the recognition.

questions.question_text: You are a Customer Support agent. A colleague invites you to an industry networking event where you can meet professionals from other gaming companies. You feel nervous about attending. What do you do?

options.text: Attend the event and prepare by researching key individuals and practicing conversation starters.
Decline the invitation because you don’t feel confident in networking.
Go to the event and avoid interacting with anyone to minimize discomfort.
Ask your colleague to attend without you and bring back any networking opportunities.

questions.question_text: You are a Customer Support agent. A customer asks for a refund because they were unable to play during a server outage. The company policy states refunds are only issued for outages over 24 hours, and this outage lasted 12 hours. The customer threatens to leave negative reviews unless refunded. What do you do?

options.text: Politely explain the refund policy, empathize with their frustration, and offer a goodwill gesture within company guidelines.
Ignore the refund request since company policy doesn’t allow for it.
Make an exception to the policy and provide a refund on the spot.
Tell the customer to escalate their request directly to management.

questions.question_text: You are a Customer Support agent for a gaming company. You’ve been working in your role for two years and are considering pursuing additional certifications in customer service to advance your career. However, the certifications are expensive. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the long-term career benefits and ROI of the certification before making a decision.
Decide against the certification because of the upfront costs.
Sign up for the certification immediately without considering its value.
Wait for your manager to recommend whether you need the certification.

title: CyberSecurity Analyst - Career Exploration
description: Experience the CyberSecurity Analyst career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Technology

questions.question_text: You are a CyberSecurity Analyst for a gaming company. During a team meeting, a junior team member incorrectly explains a security protocol, causing confusion among newer staff. What do you do?

options.text: Respectfully correct the mistake, explain the correct protocol, and offer further support to the junior team member after the meeting.
Interrupt and point out the errors immediately, ensuring everyone knows the correct protocol.
Stay silent to avoid confrontation, assuming someone else will address it later.
Privately inform the manager of the mistake and suggest the junior team member needs additional training.

questions.question_text: You are a CyberSecurity Analyst and have just identified a potential ransomware attack underway. You need to inform the development team in a way they can act quickly. What do you do?

options.text: Send an urgent email detailing the threat, affected systems, and recommended immediate actions.
Wait until the next scheduled team meeting to discuss the ransomware attack.
Call the team lead and provide a high-level overview without actionable steps.
Log the incident in the security system and trust the team will see it.

questions.question_text: You are a CyberSecurity Analyst reviewing a new gaming platform rollout. During testing, you discover a vulnerability in the login system that could expose user data. What do you do?

options.text: Immediately report the issue to the development team and assist with creating a fix before the rollout.
Document the vulnerability for later discussion in the next security review meeting.
Delay action until you confirm whether the issue affects a significant number of users.
Assume that the development team will find and address the issue on their own timeline.

questions.question_text: You are a CyberSecurity Analyst and notice a third-party tool your company is using has not been updated in six months. This tool is critical to your gaming platform’s security. What do you do?

options.text: Research the tool for known vulnerabilities, report your concerns to your manager, and suggest alternatives if the vendor is unresponsive.
Ignore the situation because the tool has been working without any visible issues.
Reach out to the vendor directly and demand they update their tool immediately.
Disable the tool without informing anyone to prevent potential vulnerabilities.

questions.question_text: You are a CyberSecurity Analyst tasked with implementing a security protocol, but the budget allocated for tools is significantly lower than expected. What do you do?

options.text: Prioritize the most critical security solutions and discuss the additional costs with your manager for approval.
Implement only the solutions that fit within the existing budget, even if some vulnerabilities are left exposed.
Skip implementing new security protocols until the next budget cycle.
Cut corners on testing and monitoring to make the solutions fit within the budget.

questions.question_text: You are a CyberSecurity Analyst monitoring a gaming network. A new vendor offers a tool that claims to reduce costs while increasing security, but you’re unsure of its reliability. Your manager asks for a recommendation. What do you do?

options.text: Conduct a thorough review of the tool’s features, security certifications, and user feedback before providing a recommendation.
Advocate for immediate adoption since it promises both cost savings and enhanced security.
Decline to consider the tool because it’s new and has unknown risks.
Recommend delaying the purchase until the vendor has been in the market longer.

questions.question_text: You are a CyberSecurity Analyst tasked with investigating a breach in your company’s gaming platform. Your established workflow requires you to collaborate with multiple teams. How do you proceed?

options.text: Follow the documented incident response procedure to gather facts, involve relevant teams, and mitigate the breach.
Focus solely on fixing the breach yourself to save time and avoid involving too many people.
Wait for your manager to assign specific tasks before taking action.
Ask the development team to temporarily disable the platform without explaining the situation.

questions.question_text: You are a CyberSecurity Analyst responsible for preparing a security audit report for a new gaming platform launch. The deadline is in three days, but you are juggling multiple tasks. What do you do?

options.text: Prioritize the audit report, delegate lower-priority tasks, and ensure the report is completed on time.
Request an extension on the audit report deadline to focus on other tasks first.
Work on the report after hours since other tasks seem more urgent.
Submit a partially completed report by the deadline and plan to finish it later.

questions.question_text: You are a CyberSecurity Analyst, and a well-known industry expert you met at a conference offers to mentor you. However, accepting this mentorship would require devoting a few hours a month outside work. What do you do?

options.text: Accept the mentorship opportunity, recognizing it will enhance your skills and professional network.
Decline the mentorship because it’s outside work hours and not part of your job.
Postpone the mentorship until your schedule is less busy.
Accept the mentorship but only if your employer is willing to adjust your hours to accommodate it.

questions.question_text: You’ve been a CyberSecurity Analyst for three years. You want to take on more responsibilities, but you’re unsure how to stand out to your manager. What do you do?

options.text: Propose taking the lead on a new security initiative and demonstrate your ability to handle more responsibility.
Wait for your manager to notice your hard work and offer you more responsibilities.
Start taking on additional responsibilities without informing your team or manager.
Focus on your current duties and avoid asking for more work to keep your stress levels low.

questions.question_text: You are a CyberSecurity Analyst, and you learn that a colleague ignored a protocol to save time, putting sensitive user data at risk. What do you do?

options.text: Report the incident to your manager and recommend steps to prevent future violations.
Ignore the issue, assuming there was no harm caused.
Confront the colleague in front of the team and demand an explanation.
Notify the client about the breach before informing your team or manager.

questions.question_text: You are considering pursuing a cybersecurity certification that could improve your skills and increase your value to your company, but it requires a significant financial investment. What do you do?

options.text: Research the certification’s benefits and request financial assistance from your employer if it aligns with company goals.
Skip the certification because the cost outweighs the immediate benefits.
Pay for the certification out of pocket without discussing it with your employer.
Wait until you’re promoted to justify the cost of the certification.

title: Equipment Manager - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Equipment Manager career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Operations & Events

questions.question_text: You are an Equipment Manager at a major gaming tournament. One of your team members is struggling to set up a critical piece of gaming hardware, and the event is about to start in 30 minutes. What do you do?

options.text: Step in to help the team member troubleshoot the issue and ensure the setup is completed on time.
Leave them to figure it out on their own to encourage independence.
Assign another team member to assist them without following up yourself.
Wait until the event coordinator asks about the delay before addressing the situation.

questions.question_text: As an Equipment Manager, you're responsible for training new interns in handling gaming equipment. One of the interns repeatedly mishandles a fragile console despite earlier instructions. What do you do?

options.text: Provide constructive feedback, demonstrate again, and monitor their work to ensure proper handling.
Ignore the issue, assuming they’ll figure it out eventually.
Reassign the intern to a simpler task and avoid further training with them.
Report the intern to your supervisor for lack of competence and recommend dismissal.

questions.question_text: You are an Equipment Manager preparing for a major online gaming event. During setup, you discover that the audio equipment for one of the gaming stations is malfunctioning. What do you do?

options.text: Quickly replace the malfunctioning equipment with a backup and test it to ensure it works.
Skip the audio setup for that station and only focus on the functioning equipment.
Inform the event manager that the station is out of service and cannot be used.
Attempt to fix the equipment on-site even though you lack the necessary tools and expertise.

questions.question_text: At a gaming event, a player reports that their controller keeps disconnecting mid-game. You check your inventory and realize you don’t have a backup controller of the same model. What do you do?

options.text: Offer a different compatible controller and ensure it is functioning properly before the player continues.
Apologize to the player and let them know there’s no solution available.
Ignore the complaint since other players are not experiencing the same issue.
Ask the player to share a controller with someone else at the event.

questions.question_text: You are an Equipment Manager for a gaming team with a tight budget. One of the team’s main monitors malfunctions, and you need to replace it quickly. What do you do?

options.text: Research and purchase a reliable, budget-friendly monitor that meets the team’s performance requirements.
Buy the cheapest monitor available, regardless of its performance.
Purchase the most expensive monitor to ensure it will last a long time.
Borrow a monitor from another team, assuming they won’t need it.

questions.question_text: Your team is preparing for a regional tournament, but the budget for equipment is significantly reduced this year. You need to decide how to allocate resources. What do you do?

options.text: Prioritize spending on the most essential equipment and repair or repurpose older items where possible.
Spend the budget equally across all equipment, regardless of importance.
Delay replacing or repairing equipment until more budget is available.
Purchase only the most expensive items to ensure the team has the best tools available, even if it means fewer items overall.

questions.question_text: You are finalizing the setup for a gaming event’s live stream. The tournament organizer informs you that the stream must start in 10 minutes. However, half the gaming consoles still need to be connected. What do you do?

options.text: Assign team members to handle the remaining setup while you focus on troubleshooting any last-minute issues.
Panic and try to set up the equipment yourself as quickly as possible.
Delay the live stream by 30 minutes to ensure everything is ready.
Ignore the remaining consoles and assume the players will figure it out when they arrive.

questions.question_text: During an intense gaming tournament, the power supply to your equipment area unexpectedly goes out. You’ve planned for this and have backup power available. What is your next step?

options.text: Quickly switch to the backup power supply while ensuring no interruption to ongoing games.
Wait until the main power is restored before resuming operations.
Apologize to the players and reschedule their games for another day.
Call for technical support and delay the event until they arrive.

questions.question_text: You are an Equipment Manager attending a national gaming convention. During a break, you overhear a vendor discussing new, innovative gaming equipment. They offer you a free demo, but it conflicts with a networking session. What do you do?

options.text: Attend the networking session to build relationships and prioritize the demo for a later time.
Skip the networking session and immediately attend the demo.
Decline the demo and focus solely on networking.
Ignore both opportunities and take the break to relax.

questions.question_text: You’re an Equipment Manager interested in advancing your career. You enjoy managing equipment for gaming tournaments and want to grow within the industry. What is your next step?

options.text: Research advanced certifications or training programs to further your skills and stay competitive.
Stick to your current position until a promotion is offered.
Focus solely on doing your current job well and avoid additional responsibilities.
Wait for opportunities to come to you rather than actively seeking them out.

questions.question_text: You are an Equipment Manager purchasing supplies for the next tournament. One vendor offers you a discount but insists on cash payment without providing receipts. What do you do?

options.text: Decline the offer and only purchase equipment from a vendor that provides official receipts.
Accept the offer to save the organization money.
Negotiate a better deal and still accept cash-only payments without receipts.
Purchase from a different vendor without verifying their credentials to save time.

questions.question_text: You are taking a course to improve your technical knowledge as an Equipment Manager. However, a last-minute event requires your attention during class hours. How do you respond?

options.text: Coordinate with your supervisor to manage event responsibilities while attending the course.
Skip the class and attend the event, assuming the skills can be learned later.
Reschedule the event to a more convenient time, even if it inconveniences others.

title: Esports Agent - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Esports Agent career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Esports Operations

questions.question_text: You are an Esports Agent and one of your clients has a disagreement with a teammate about how prize money should be split after winning a major tournament. options.text: Arrange a meeting with both players to mediate the disagreement and find a fair solution for both parties.
