questions.question_text: You are an Esports Agent overseeing a client's team during a critical championship. During an intermission, you overhear one of the team members yelling at your client, causing visible tension among the group. The team is about to start the next match soon. What do you do?

options.text: Privately speak with the team member to de-escalate the conflict and encourage a focus on the upcoming match.
Confront the team member in front of the entire team to assert authority and resolve the issue quickly.
Ignore the situation since the match is about to start and focus on strategic advice instead.
Advise your client to leave the team immediately and look for a less toxic environment after the match.

Advise your client to accept the deal for exposure purposes, as it will help grow their brand.
Counter with a proposal that provides more equipment rather than monetary compensation.
Decline the sponsorship offer entirely and encourage your client to seek better opportunities elsewhere.

questions.question_text: You are an Esports Agent negotiating tournament prize winnings for your client. The tournament organizer has offered a payout structure that disproportionately favors first place but penalizes lower rankings, which your client feels is unfair. What do you do?

options.text: Negotiate with the organizer to revise the prize distribution to be more balanced for mid-tier placements.
Advise your client to participate anyway, explaining that this is standard practice in the industry.
Threaten to withdraw your client's participation unless the prize structure is fixed.
Suggest your client focus solely on winning first place to maximize earnings.

You realize the client has not reviewed their game strategies and is relying solely on past performances. With the tournament only days away, you need to ensure they are ready to compete at a high level. What do you do?

Assume your client's past performances are enough and let them compete without additional preparation.

Encourage your client to focus on physical well-being instead of game strategies for the tournament.

questions.question_text: You are an Esports Agent tasked with reviewing a new streaming contract for your client with a popular platform. options.text: Request amendments to the exclusivity clause to allow flexible collaborations with other streaming platforms.
Advise your client to sign the contract immediately to lock in a deal with a popular platform.
Ignore the exclusivity clause since it does not impact current revenue streams.

options.text: Help your client reorganize their schedule to include the break while maintaining some level of activity online.
Convince your client to keep streaming despite their mental health concerns to protect their viewership numbers.
Cancel the break and reduce streaming hours instead to keep viewers engaged without overburdening your client.

questions.question_text: You are an Esports Agent organizing your client's participation in a multi-day tournament held in a foreign country. A sudden schedule change means your client now has back-to-back matches in two venues hours apart. You need to adjust travel plans. What do you do?

options.text: Coordinate with the tournament organizers to arrange transportation and request an adjusted schedule if possible.
Book an additional flight for your client without consulting the tournament organizers.
Encourage your client to stay at one venue and forfeit the other matches to focus on the main tournament.
Ask your client to travel independently between matches to avoid organizational delays.

questions.question_text: You are an Esports Agent attending an industry networking event. You notice that a representative from a major esports team is present, but they seem busy socializing with others and less approachable. options.text: Wait for an opportunity to approach them directly and introduce yourself and your client in a professional manner.
Decide not to bother them since they look busy and you don’t want to interrupt.
Send them an email after the event instead and skip introducing yourself in person.
Approach them while they are talking with someone else to ensure you secure their attention.

questions.question_text: You are an Esports Agent helping your client who is trying to transition from competing in tournaments to becoming a full-time content creator. Your client is worried that their fan base will lose interest if they don’t participate in tournaments anymore. What do you do?

options.text: Develop a strategy that includes engaging content creation while keeping the option of participating in selective tournaments open.
Encourage your client to fully stop competing and focus all efforts on content creation.
Advise your client to maintain their current tournament schedule while occasionally streaming content.

questions.question_text: You are an Esports Agent and a potential client offers to hire you for representation but wants you to prioritize them over your current clients. The new client has significant earning potential, but agreeing to their terms could harm your relationship with existing clients. What do you do?

options.text: Decline the offer and explain that you value fairness and transparency with all your clients.
Accept the offer and prioritize the new client since they have higher potential earnings.
Agree to the new client’s terms but secretly maintain equal focus on all your clients.
Drop your existing clients to fully dedicate your time to the new client.

questions.question_text: You are an Esports Agent considering additional certifications to help elevate your career and attract higher-profile clients. You find a program focused on advanced negotiation strategies, but it’s costly and will require a significant time commitment. What do you do?

options.text: Invest in the certification, as it aligns with your career goals and skill development.
Skip the certification and focus on building experience in the industry instead.
Wait until you have a larger client base before pursuing certifications.
Look for a cheaper program, even if it doesn’t address negotiation strategies specifically.

subject: Esports Operations

questions.question_text: You are an Esports Analyst working with a team preparing for a major tournament. A player on the team is struggling to adapt to the new game patch, and it’s affecting their performance. What do you do?

Ignore the error to avoid creating tension with your colleague and proceed with the presentation.
Correct the error yourself without informing your colleague to save time.

options.text: Create a detailed report outlining the specific weakness and suggest new strategies to address it.
Ignore the weakness since your team has been winning despite the issue.

options.text: Choose the cheaper tool and test it to see if it meets your team’s needs.
Try to negotiate with your manager for a larger budget to purchase the better tool.
Spend your own money to cover the difference and buy the better tool.
Delay the decision until more funds become available.

options.text: Focus on analyzing only the updated aspects of the patch that are most likely to impact your team.
Redo the entire analysis from scratch, even if it risks missing the deadline.

options.text: Use the available data to create the report but highlight the missing information and its potential impact.

questions.question_text: You are attending a live tournament and meet a high-profile team manager. They express interest in your analysis and ask for your contact information. What do you do?

options.text: Introduce yourself, share your contact information, and offer to discuss opportunities to collaborate.
Give them your contact information but avoid further conversation to stay professional.
Mention your work briefly but avoid sharing your contact information unless they insist.

options.text: Discuss the proposal with your manager and weigh the potential benefits of the partnership for your organization.
Immediately decline the offer to avoid any conflicts of interest.
Accept the offer without consulting your team, as it could benefit your career.
Keep the offer to yourself and wait until after the next tournament to make a decision.

questions.question_text: You are an Esports Analyst deciding whether to enroll in a certification program to improve your data visualization skills. It’s expensive but could help you stand out in the industry. What do you do?

options.text: Enroll in the certification program after creating a budget to manage the cost.

Sign up for the program without considering your current schedule or finances.

Inform the executive that upgrading the lighting system is unnecessary at this time.
Suggest no changes and keep the current system to avoid disruptions.

questions.question_text: You are a Facilities Manager, and you have been tasked with reducing the monthly maintenance budget by 10%. What do you do?

options.text: Prioritize essential maintenance tasks and negotiate better rates with contractors.
Cut back on all maintenance tasks to meet the budget reduction target.
Delay any maintenance work until a new budget is allocated.
Reduce the frequency of safety inspections to save costs.

questions.question_text: You are a Facilities Manager overseeing a large gaming venue. You notice that the utility bills have doubled over the past two months. What do you do?

options.text: Investigate usage patterns and identify potential inefficiencies or issues causing the increase.
Reduce maintenance to save costs and cover the higher utility bills.
Ignore the higher bills since it’s likely a temporary fluctuation.
Blame the utility company and demand a refund without investigating the issue.

questions.question_text: You are a Facilities Manager, and a major gaming event is scheduled at the venue. To prepare, you need to ensure all operational tasks are on schedule. During the final walkthrough, you notice that several setups are incomplete. What do you do?

options.text: Communicate with your team immediately, prioritize the pending tasks, and allocate additional resources to complete them.
Delay the event to allow more time for preparation.
Ignore the incomplete setups and hope attendees won’t notice.
Reallocate your team’s efforts without informing them about the urgency.

questions.question_text: You are a Facilities Manager tasked with ensuring all safety protocols are followed during operations. You notice one of your new hires is not wearing proper safety gear while performing maintenance on an arcade machine. What do you do?

options.text: Pause their work immediately to ensure safety and provide proper training on equipment protocols.
Allow them to continue and address the issue during the next scheduled training session.
Report them to HR for violating safety policies.
Ignore the situation since they are new and may not know the rules yet.

questions.question_text: You are a Facilities Manager, and a gaming hardware vendor approaches you with a proposal to upgrade your venue's equipment. The vendor promises a 20% increase in operational efficiency, but the cost is significantly above your current budget. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the long-term benefits and negotiate a better price or phased payment plan if the upgrade is worthwhile.
Reject the proposal outright due to the high cost.
Accept the proposal immediately to achieve the promised efficiency gains.
Ask the vendor to come back after next fiscal year when you have a higher budget.

questions.question_text: You are a Facilities Manager attending a networking event for gaming industry professionals. A potential client expresses interest in hiring your team for a new large-scale gaming venue project. What do you do?

options.text: Exchange contact information, follow up with a formal proposal, and highlight your team’s expertise.
Give a verbal agreement to take on the project without discussing details.
Ignore the opportunity as your team is already busy with current projects.
Tell the client to reach out directly to your company’s general contact email.

questions.question_text: You are a Facilities Manager, and you notice that the gaming venue's HVAC system is outdated and inefficient, leading to higher energy bills and frequent repairs. Management is hesitant to approve replacements due to upfront costs. What do you do?

options.text: Present a cost-benefit analysis showing long-term energy savings and reduced repair costs to justify the investment.
Continue running the outdated system to avoid conflict with management.
Propose replacing only the most damaged part to minimize costs.
Secure temporary fixes until the next fiscal year when budgets are renewed.

questions.question_text: You are a Facilities Manager considering whether to pursue a professional certification in advanced facilities technology. The certification would require a significant investment of time and money, but it could boost your career. What do you do?

options.text: Enroll in the certification, recognizing the long-term benefits it could bring to your career.
Decide against the certification because you already have a stable job.
Wait until your employer offers to sponsor the certification cost.
Take the certification only if your peers are also doing it.

title: Financial Analyst - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Financial Analyst career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Business & Finance

questions.question_text: You are a Financial Analyst at a gaming company. Your manager schedules a meeting to discuss budget forecasts with the product development team. During the meeting, you notice the team’s communication is unclear and conflicts arise regarding the accuracy of the financial assumptions. What do you do?

options.text: Suggest setting up a follow-up meeting with clearer agendas and facilitate collaboration between teams to align assumptions.
Ignore the conflict and focus solely on your own financial analysis tasks.
Side with the manager’s perspective without addressing the assumptions issue.
Take control of the meeting and dismiss other opinions to move forward quickly.

questions.question_text: You are a Financial Analyst tasked with mentoring a junior analyst who is struggling to deliver accurate reports. Their errors are causing delays in your work. How do you handle this situation?

options.text: Schedule one-on-one coaching sessions, review their work closely, and provide constructive feedback.
Complete their tasks yourself to ensure accuracy and avoid delays.
Report their mistakes directly to your manager without attempting to mentor them.
Ignore their errors and focus on completing your own work.

questions.question_text: You are a Financial Analyst preparing a report to evaluate the profitability of a new gaming console. The data you received from the sales team is incomplete. What do you do?

options.text: Request the missing data from the sales team and delay the report deadline until all information is available.
Proceed with the report using the incomplete data and make assumptions to fill gaps.
Skip the profitability section and focus on other elements of the report.
Use outdated data from a similar console to complete the report.

questions.question_text: You are a Financial Analyst working on a project that involves creating a financial model for a new gaming subscription service. The spreadsheet tool you’re using frequently crashes. How do you resolve this issue?

options.text: Switch to a more reliable software tool and rebuild the model with improved functionality.
Continue using the crashing tool and save your work frequently to avoid data loss.
Abandon the model altogether and focus on verbal communication about financial projections.
Ask your manager for an extension without addressing the tool issue.

questions.question_text: You are a Financial Analyst tasked with forecasting financial returns for the launch of a new game. The marketing team proposes a high-cost campaign that exceeds the allocated budget. How do you respond?

options.text: Present alternate strategies with cost-effective options and demonstrate their impact on financial returns.
Approve the campaign without further analysis since marketing is confident it will succeed.
Reject the proposal outright and suggest cutting marketing budgets entirely.
Ignore the discrepancy and proceed without adjusting the budget.

questions.question_text: You are a Financial Analyst reviewing expenses for your department. You notice a recurring vendor charge that appears unusually high but has gone unquestioned for months. What do you do?

options.text: Investigate the charges, reach out to the vendor for clarification, and verify the service was necessary.
Assume the charges are valid since they’ve been approved previously.
Report the charges to your manager immediately without further investigation.
Remove the vendor from future budgets without consulting others.

questions.question_text: You are a Financial Analyst managing deadlines for monthly financial close procedures. Several team members are late submitting their data, jeopardizing the completion timeline. What do you do?

options.text: Follow up with team members, offer assistance if needed, and set clear expectations for future deadlines.
Skip their input and proceed with closing the books using incomplete data.
Rush through your portion of the work to make up for lost time.
Blame the team members for delays and escalate the issue to your manager.

questions.question_text: You are a Financial Analyst working on compiling quarterly reports for executive review. The company recently updated its reporting software, but you are unfamiliar with the new system. What do you do?

options.text: Dedicate time to learn the new software and seek help from IT if you encounter issues.
Continue using the old software and disregard the company’s updates.
Submit incomplete reports while you attempt to understand the new system.
Delay the reports and wait until a training session is offered.

questions.question_text: You are a Financial Analyst who wants to advance your career. A networking opportunity arises at an industry conference, but you're unsure how to maximize your time there. What do you do?

options.text: Research key speakers, attend relevant panels, and actively introduce yourself to professionals in your field.
Spend most of your time attending general sessions without interacting with others.
Skip the conference because you don’t feel prepared to network effectively.
Focus only on distributing your resume without learning from others.

questions.question_text: You are a Financial Analyst exploring a promotion opportunity. Your manager asks for proof of your contributions to help justify the promotion. How do you respond?

options.text: Compile a detailed report showcasing your analysis work, successful forecasts, and their impact on company profits.
Mention your hard work verbally but provide no tangible evidence of your achievements.
Ask your colleagues to vouch for your performance instead of providing documentation.
Decline the opportunity because compiling proof feels overwhelming.

questions.question_text: You are a Financial Analyst responsible for assessing ROI for a new gaming project. The project leader suggests inflating the numbers to attract executive approval. What do you do?

options.text: Refuse to inflate the numbers, present honest ROI calculations, and explain the long-term benefits of integrity.
Agree to inflate the numbers to ensure the project gets approved.
Avoid addressing the suggestion and proceed with your current analysis without saying anything.
Report the project leader’s suggestion to your manager immediately without completing the analysis.

questions.question_text: You are a Financial Analyst considering enrolling in a certification course to enhance your data analysis skills. However, it requires significant financial and time investment. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the course’s relevance to your career goals and return on investment, and enroll if it aligns with long-term benefits.
Enroll immediately without researching whether the certification is valued in your industry.
Decide against enrolling to avoid spending money, regardless of long-term career potential.
Ask your manager for immediate financial assistance without demonstrating its value.

title: Fitness Coach - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Fitness Coach career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Health & Wellness

questions.question_text: You are a Fitness Coach working with an esports team. One of the players is struggling with a workout and seems frustrated. They tell you they don't think your program is helping them. What do you do?

options.text: Ask for specific feedback and adjust the program to better suit their needs.
Tell them to stick to the program because you know what's best for their performance.
Ignore their concerns because adjusting the program would take too much time.
Suggest they talk to the team manager instead of addressing their concerns yourself.

questions.question_text: You are a Fitness Coach supervising a training session. One of your colleagues suggests a new warm-up technique that you have never used before. How do you respond?

options.text: Discuss the method with them and evaluate if it aligns with your team's needs before trying it.
Dismiss their suggestion because you already have a tried-and-tested routine.
Immediately implement the technique without knowing how it works.
Tell them to consult the head coach instead of bringing it up to you.

questions.question_text: You are a Fitness Coach designing a new workout program for an esports team. The players need exercises that improve reaction times and reduce fatigue during gameplay. What do you do?

options.text: Research exercises that improve cognitive function and stamina, tailoring the program to their needs.
Use a generic workout routine without considering the esports-specific requirements.
Focus solely on strength training, as it seems the most straightforward.
Ask the players to tell you what they think they need and base the program entirely on that.

questions.question_text: You are a Fitness Coach working with esports athletes, and you notice that the gym equipment is worn out and could be unsafe. What do you do?

options.text: Report the issue to the facility manager and request the equipment be repaired or replaced immediately.
Continue using the equipment until it completely breaks down.
Ask the players to use the equipment but tell them to be extra careful.
Stop using the equipment but make no effort to report the issue.

questions.question_text: You are a Fitness Coach, and the esports organization has a limited budget for new training equipment. How do you ensure the players still get effective workouts?

options.text: Focus on bodyweight exercises and make creative use of the equipment you already have.
Reduce the frequency of training sessions to save on equipment wear and tear.
Purchase expensive equipment using your own money to make up for the budget shortfall.
Discontinue the workout program until new equipment can be purchased.

questions.question_text: You are a Fitness Coach preparing a budget proposal for a new training program. The organization asks you to cut costs by 20%. What do you do?

options.text: Adjust the program to focus on lower-cost yet effective training methods, ensuring quality isn't compromised.
Eliminate key components of the program to meet the budget requirements.
Ignore the request and submit the original budget proposal.
Suggest canceling the program entirely due to the reduced budget.

questions.question_text: You are a Fitness Coach managing multiple players' programs. One player asks for more time to review their performance data before starting their workout, which delays the schedule. What do you do?

options.text: Adjust the schedule slightly, ensuring the overall session stays on track.
Ignore their request and tell them to focus on the workout plan as scheduled.
Completely rearrange the schedule based on their preferences.
Cancel their workout for the day to avoid disruptions.

questions.question_text: You are a Fitness Coach conducting a group training session. A player uses improper form during an exercise, putting themselves at risk of injury. What do you do?

options.text: Pause the session to correct their form and ensure everyone is performing the exercises safely.
Ignore it to avoid disrupting the group session.
Tell the player to stop participating for the rest of the session.
Explain the proper form to the group afterward, but don't address it during the session.

questions.question_text: You are a Fitness Coach, and a player praises your training program during a live interview, giving you public recognition. How do you leverage this opportunity?

options.text: Share the interview on your professional social media and thank the player publicly.
Ask the player to stop talking about you publicly to avoid attention.
Ignore the recognition and continue without any acknowledgment.
Privately message the player to demand more public praise.

questions.question_text: You are a Fitness Coach building your career in esports. A well-known team offers you a part-time role, but you’re currently working full-time with another organization. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the new opportunity's long-term potential and discuss options with your current employer.
Immediately quit your current role and join the new team without considering the consequences.
Decline the new role without exploring its benefits.
Take on both roles without informing your current employer.

questions.question_text: You are a Fitness Coach considering a certification in esports-specific training. The course is expensive but highly regarded. What do you do?

options.text: Invest in the certification, as it will boost your credibility and help you secure better opportunities.
Avoid spending money on the certification because it’s too expensive.
Take the course but skip some of the required classes to save time.
Wait until the course offers a discount, even if it means delaying your career growth.

questions.question_text: You are a Fitness Coach, and the organization you work for asks you to train their players despite knowing the training environment is unsafe. What do you do?

options.text: Refuse to proceed with training until the environment is made safe, prioritizing player safety.
Train the players anyway, as long as they sign a waiver.
Ask the players if they feel comfortable and let them decide whether to train or not.
Continue training and avoid addressing any potential hazards to keep your job.

title: Game Designer - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Game Designer career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Creative & Technology

questions.question_text: You are a Game Designer working with a team of artists and programmers on a new adventure game. One of the programmers is struggling to implement a mechanic you designed, and they seem frustrated. What do you do?

options.text: Offer to explain the mechanic in more detail and provide a visual example to help clarify expectations.
Tell them to figure it out on their own since your job is only to design.
Ignore the issue and focus on designing the next game level.
Request that the project manager deal with the programmer directly.

questions.question_text: You’re leading a brainstorming session with your team to generate ideas for a game’s storyline. One colleague keeps dismissing others’ ideas and insisting their own ideas are better. This is disrupting the collaboration. What do you do?

options.text: Politely intervene, encouraging everyone to share ideas and reminding the team about the importance of collaboration.
Ignore the situation and let the colleague dominate the conversation to keep things moving.
End the meeting early and work on the storyline yourself to avoid further conflict.
Criticize the colleague in front of the group to send a message that their behavior is unacceptable.

questions.question_text: You are designing a new game level and your manager wants it to stand out from competitors by incorporating new mechanics. However, you realize that the mechanics you've developed are too complex for most players to understand during gameplay. What do you do?

options.text: Simplify the mechanics while maintaining innovation to ensure the game is accessible and enjoyable for players.
Ignore the issue and keep the mechanics as they are to meet the deadline quickly.
Cut the new mechanics entirely and replace them with standard ones already used in previous games.
Ask the programmers to figure out how to make the mechanics easier without revising your designs.

questions.question_text: You are tasked with designing the visual theme for a role-playing game. You want the game’s art style to be unique, but when comparing your ideas to current industry trends, your concept doesn’t seem to resonate with the target audience. What do you do?

options.text: Revisit audience feedback and adapt your visual theme to align with current preferences while retaining originality.
Stick with your original concept, believing players will eventually appreciate your unique vision.
Scrap the theme entirely and copy the art style of a popular game.
Ask your manager to make the final decision on the visual theme.

questions.question_text: You are designing a game’s budget plan and realize the cost of acquiring software tools might exceed the allocated budget. What do you do?

options.text: Research alternative tools that offer the required functionality at a lower cost to stay within budget.
Use personal funds to cover the gap for the sake of completing the project quickly.
Ignore the issue and proceed with the current tools, hoping the company will cover the extra expense later.
Request immediate approval to increase the budget without providing justification.

questions.question_text: You are pitching a game idea to a publisher. They love the concept but ask you to reduce the costs of production significantly, which may compromise the overall quality of the game. What do you do?

options.text: Work with your team to revise the production plan, optimizing costs while maintaining the game's core features and quality.
Agree to cut costs immediately without evaluating the impact on the game’s quality.
Refuse to reduce costs and risk losing the publisher’s support.
Allow the publisher to decide which areas of production to cut costs.

questions.question_text: You are leading the development process for a new game. The deadline is only two weeks away, but your team is behind schedule. Several bugs need fixing before you can move forward. What do you do?

options.text: Prioritize bug fixes by reallocating team resources and extending work hours temporarily to meet the deadline.
Ignore the bugs and focus on completing other tasks to avoid falling further behind.
Delay the deadline by another month without discussing it with your manager.
Outsource the bug fixes to an external team without notifying your team.

questions.question_text: You are planning the workflow process for creating game levels, but you notice that your team has been working inefficiently due to unclear task assignments. Deadlines are slipping as a result. What do you do?

options.text: Clarify each team member’s responsibilities and create a detailed project timeline to improve efficiency.
Send a team-wide email urging everyone to work harder without addressing specific tasks or deadlines.
Delegate the workflow planning tasks to the senior programmer, even though it’s not their area of expertise.
Cancel all current deadlines to give the team more flexibility.

questions.question_text: You are attending a networking event with other game designers and industry professionals. A famous designer asks about your current project, which hasn’t been announced yet. What do you do?

options.text: Share general information about your project without revealing confidential details.
Provide detailed information about your project to impress the designer.
Refuse to answer any questions and leave the conversation abruptly.
Ask the designer to sign a non-disclosure agreement before discussing anything.

questions.question_text: You receive an invitation to speak at a gaming conference about your recent successes. The event would help establish your reputation in the industry, but it's scheduled during a crunch period for your current project. What do you do?

options.text: Plan your schedule to attend the conference while ensuring your current responsibilities are managed effectively.
Decline the invitation, focusing solely on your project deadlines.
Accept the invitation and postpone your project deadlines without telling your team.
Request that your manager handle your speaking responsibilities at the conference.

questions.question_text: You are a Game Designer and find out that your company is considering layoffs due to financial challenges. You have an opportunity to propose cost-efficient game ideas that could increase profits. What do you do?

options.text: Present a well-thought-out proposal for cost-efficient game ideas that balance quality and profitability.
Focus on your current tasks without engaging in the company's financial discussions.
Resign immediately to avoid being laid off.
Suggest cutting costs by eliminating non-essential team roles.

questions.question_text: You’ve been offered funding to acquire advanced design software that could greatly boost your productivity, but it requires a significant financial investment upfront. What do you do?

options.text: Assess the long-term benefits and ROI of purchasing the software before making a decision.
Reject the funding and continue using your current tools to avoid the financial risk.
Accept the funding immediately without evaluating its impact.
Request additional funding for other resources without addressing the software need.

title: General Manager - Career Exploration
description: Experience the General Manager career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Business & Finance

questions.question_text: You are a General Manager of a mid-sized gaming company. One of your senior team members is repeatedly missing deadlines, which is causing frustration among the team. What do you do?

options.text: Have a one-on-one meeting with the team member to understand the root cause and provide support or resources to improve.
Send an email to the entire team highlighting the missed deadlines to pressure the team member into performing.
Ignore the issue for now and hope the team member improves on their own.
Publicly reprimand the team member during the next team meeting to set an example.

questions.question_text: You are a General Manager, and one of your most talented employees has expressed feeling undervalued and is considering leaving the company. What do you do?

options.text: Schedule a private conversation to discuss their concerns and explore ways to address them, such as new challenges or a clear growth path.
Tell them that everyone feels undervalued sometimes and that they should focus on their work.
Ignore their concerns—it’s not your job to cater to every employee’s feelings.
Offer them a salary increase immediately to keep them from leaving.

questions.question_text: You are a General Manager, and your company is preparing to launch a new gaming product. During testing, the QA team discovers a minor bug that might affect gameplay in certain scenarios. Fixing it will delay the launch by two weeks. What do you do?

options.text: Delay the launch to fix the bug, ensuring the product quality meets customer expectations.
Ignore the bug and proceed with the launch as planned, as it’s unlikely many users will encounter it.
Launch the product and plan to release a fix in a later update.
Cancel the launch altogether until the team is certain no other bugs exist.

questions.question_text: You are a General Manager, and your marketing team suggests using a new software tool to analyze the performance of your gaming product. It’s expensive and will require training for some staff. What do you do?

options.text: Research the tool’s benefits, consult with the team about its necessity, and calculate its return on investment before making a decision.
Approve the purchase immediately, trusting your team’s recommendation.
Refuse to consider it because the current tools are functional, even if outdated.
Delay the decision indefinitely because it’s too costly and complex.

questions.question_text: You are a General Manager, and your finance team has informed you that a recent game development project is running over budget. You’re scheduled for a meeting with the board. How do you prepare for the discussion?

options.text: Analyze the reasons behind the overspending and propose specific cost-saving measures for the next phase of the project.
Blame the development team for mismanaging resources and request an increased budget.
Delay the meeting until you can bring the project back under budget.
Focus on defending the current spending as necessary without having a detailed plan for the future.

questions.question_text: You are a General Manager for a gaming company and are considering pricing for a new game release. Your team suggests a higher price point for premium features, but this could alienate some customers. What do you do?

options.text: Conduct market research to assess the willingness to pay and adjust pricing accordingly.
Set the price lower to ensure maximum customer satisfaction and sales volume.
Set the price higher without research, focusing on maximizing short-term profits.
Offer the game for free and monetize through ads only.

questions.question_text: You are a General Manager, and your company has just implemented a new workflow for game development. Some employees are struggling to adapt to the changes. What do you do?

options.text: Organize a training session and provide resources to help employees understand and adapt to the new workflow.
Tell employees to figure it out on their own, as this will encourage independent learning.
Revert to the old workflow to avoid further inefficiencies.
Ignore the issue and let employees adapt at their own pace.

questions.question_text: You are a General Manager, and a key project is falling behind schedule. The team is working overtime, but it’s still not enough to meet the deadline. What do you do?

options.text: Assess the project timeline, identify critical bottlenecks, and reallocate resources to ensure the most pressing tasks are completed on time.
Instruct the team to continue working overtime until the project is completed.
Inform the client that the deadline can’t be met and request an extension.
Cancel parts of the project to make up for lost time.

questions.question_text: You are a General Manager, and you’ve been invited to a major industry event that could lead to partnerships and increased revenue. However, you have an important internal meeting scheduled at the same time. What do you do?

options.text: Delegate the internal meeting to a trusted senior manager and attend the industry event to build partnerships.
Skip the industry event and attend the internal meeting to ensure it goes as planned.
Cancel the internal meeting and reschedule it to a later date without assigning anyone to lead it.
Skip both the meeting and the event to avoid making a difficult decision.

questions.question_text: You are a General Manager, and a potential client has expressed interest in partnering with your company. They bring significant revenue potential but have a history of breaking contracts. How do you proceed?

options.text: Conduct a thorough background check and propose a contract with terms that mitigate risk.
Immediately agree to the partnership to secure the revenue opportunity.
Decline the opportunity due to their history, even if it means losing potential revenue.
Ignore the client’s history and proceed with a standard contract.

questions.question_text: You are a General Manager, and you’ve discovered that a vendor is overcharging your company for services. What do you do?

options.text: Compare their pricing with other vendors, renegotiate the contract, or switch to a more cost-effective provider.
Continue using the vendor to avoid disrupting operations.
Confront the vendor aggressively and threaten to terminate the contract immediately.
Ignore the issue and assume the vendor had a valid reason for the higher charges.

questions.question_text: You are a General Manager, and you’ve been offered a lucrative opportunity to cut costs by outsourcing work to a vendor in another country. However, you’ve heard concerns about unethical labor practices in that region. What do you do?

options.text: Research the vendor's labor practices thoroughly and only proceed if they adhere to ethical labor standards.
Proceed with outsourcing to save money and deal with potential backlash later.
Ignore the opportunity altogether to avoid any potential controversy.
Seek a less profitable alternative without investigating the current vendor’s labor practices.

title: Graphic Designer - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Graphic Designer career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Creative & Media

questions.question_text: You are a Graphic Designer working on a gaming project with your team. A colleague submits their portion of the graphics, but the design feels outdated and doesn’t align with the modern look of the game. What do you do?

options.text: Discuss your concerns respectfully with the colleague and offer constructive feedback to align their design with the project.
Redo their design yourself without notifying them to save time.
Ignore the design issue and submit the project as is.
Report the colleague’s work to your manager without speaking to them directly.

questions.question_text: You are a Graphic Designer leading a brainstorming session for a game’s promotional material. A junior team member proposes an idea that you think is overly simplistic. What do you do?

options.text: Encourage them to elaborate on the idea and explore ways to refine it further with the team.
Immediately dismiss their idea to keep the process moving.
Replace their idea with your own, assuming your experience makes yours better.
Ignore the idea and focus on other suggestions without giving them feedback.

questions.question_text: You are a Graphic Designer tasked with creating in-game textures. Halfway through, you notice the texture resolution doesn’t meet the client’s high-definition requirements. What do you do?

options.text: Redo the textures at the correct resolution, ensuring they meet the client's quality standards.
Submit the textures anyway, hoping the client won’t notice the resolution issue.
Inform the client that the resolution is lower but explain it would save time.
Delay the delivery without explanation while trying to fix the textures.

questions.question_text: You are a Graphic Designer using new software to create game character assets. Midway, the software crashes, and you lose several hours of progress. What do you do?

options.text: Quickly recreate the lost assets while saving frequently and looking for solutions to prevent future crashes.
Submit what you’ve already done and blame the software for the incomplete work.
Request more time to resolve the issue without offering solutions.
Switch to different software, even if it disrupts the workflow and consistency of the designs.

questions.question_text: You are a Graphic Designer preparing cost estimates for the graphics in a new gaming project. The client has a limited budget but wants high-quality assets. What do you do?

options.text: Identify cost-effective design approaches and discuss options with the client to manage expectations.
Agree to everything the client wants without considering the budget constraints.
Refuse the project due to the limited budget without exploring alternatives.
Use cheaper, lower-quality tools without informing the client to reduce production costs.

questions.question_text: You are a Graphic Designer and your manager asks for a breakdown of costs for potential downloadable content (DLC) graphics. You realize you underestimated the time needed for creation. How do you handle this?

options.text: Update the cost breakdown with the accurate timeframe and explain the reasoning to your manager.
Ignore the discrepancy and continue with the lower estimate.
Increase the costs without informing your manager why.
Rush through the designs to meet the original timeline estimate.

questions.question_text: You are a Graphic Designer with fast-approaching deadlines for several projects. A new urgent request comes in. What do you do?

options.text: Prioritize and schedule the new request alongside your current tasks while communicating any adjustments to deadlines.
Drop the existing projects entirely to focus on the urgent request.
Ignore the urgent request and continue working on the original tasks.
Rush through all projects to meet deadlines, sacrificing quality for speed.

questions.question_text: You are a Graphic Designer creating concept art for a character when your manager informs you that the project’s art style has changed. You’ve invested significant time into your current work. What do you do?

options.text: Adapt your design to align with the new art style, even if it means redoing your work.
Continue your current design and hope the team incorporates it as is.
Request an extension for the project but don’t start adapting your work until it’s approved.
Abandon your project altogether and start a new one from scratch without informing your manager.

questions.question_text: You are a Graphic Designer and you notice that a gaming client you worked with last year is now releasing new projects. What do you do?

options.text: Reach out professionally to inquire about potential collaboration opportunities for their new projects.
Wait for them to contact you first about any future work.
Send them a casual message on social media asking for work.
Ignore the situation and focus only on your current clients.

questions.question_text: You are a Graphic Designer aiming for a promotion. Your manager suggests creating a portfolio to present during your annual review. What do you do?

options.text: Curate a portfolio showcasing your best and most recent work, with clear descriptions of your contributions.
Include all past projects in the portfolio without editing or selecting the best ones.
Create a portfolio but neglect to describe your contributions or impact.
Ignore the suggestion and assume your manager knows your value without a portfolio.

questions.question_text: You are a Graphic Designer and a colleague suggests cutting corners on a project to save time. The company needs this project completed quickly, but you know the quality may suffer. What do you do?

options.text: Insist on maintaining quality and propose other ways to meet the deadline more efficiently.
Agree to cut corners since the deadline is more important than quality.
Secretly fix the mistakes yourself without informing your colleague, delaying the project.
Dismiss your colleague’s idea but avoid explaining your reasoning.

questions.question_text: You are a Graphic Designer considering enrolling in an advanced 3D modeling course to improve your skills. The course is expensive but could benefit your long-term career. What do you do?

options.text: Enroll in the course after research shows it aligns with your career goals and will increase your earning potential.
Skip the course to avoid the expense, and continue using your current skill set.
Take the course immediately without considering how it fits into your long-term plans.
Ask your employer to pay for the course without preparing a pitch about its benefits to the company.

title: Head Chef - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Head Chef career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Operations & Support

questions.question_text: You are a Head Chef in a gaming team facility kitchen. One of your sous chefs has been consistently late to shifts, causing tension among the rest of the kitchen team. Today, the sous chef is late again, and the team is voicing their frustrations. What do you do?

options.text: Call the sous chef aside for a private conversation, address the lateness issue professionally, and offer support to help them improve while ensuring team harmony.
Publicly reprimand the sous chef in front of the team to set an example.
Ignore the issue and hope the sous chef improves on their own.
Assign another team member to cover the sous chef’s responsibilities without addressing their lateness.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Chef. One of your line cooks repeatedly fails to follow plating instructions, leading to inconsistent dishes being served. Customers have started complaining about the presentation of their meals. What do you do?

options.text: Provide the line cook with additional training, a clear explanation of plating standards, and closely monitor their work for improvement.
Remove the line cook from plating duties and redistribute their tasks to other team members.
Let the complaints continue, as long as the food tastes good.
Confront the line cook aggressively about their mistakes to ensure compliance.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Chef tasked with designing a new post-game menu for the gaming team. The team manager wants dishes that balance nutrition with flavor and can be prepared quickly after games. What do you do?

options.text: Create a menu with healthy, flavorful options that focus on efficiency, using seasonally available ingredients to minimize prep time.
Keep the menu the same, focusing on comfort food despite high preparation times.
Design a menu with only protein-heavy, bland dishes to emphasize nutrition over flavor.
Include elaborate meals requiring long preparation, prioritizing complexity over practicality.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Chef planning a special dinner service for a major event at the gaming facility. During prep, you notice that the blender used for soups has broken down, and you need to improvise. What do you do?

options.text: Use an alternative tool, such as a food processor, to blend the soups and ensure service runs smoothly.
Skip serving the soup and ask the team to focus only on other dishes.
Stop all food prep to try and fix the broken blender.
Serve the soups unblended and explain the issue to customers after service.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Chef managing the kitchen budget. You notice that the team’s favorite premium tuna supplier has increased their prices significantly, putting strain on your budget. What do you do?

options.text: Research alternative suppliers for similar quality tuna at a lower cost and adjust the menu accordingly.
Keep ordering from the premium supplier despite the increased cost to maintain consistency.
Switch to a cheaper supplier without researching the quality of their tuna.
Remove tuna dishes from the menu entirely without consulting the team or manager.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Chef, and a large order of specialty ingredients was accidentally double-billed, causing a major strain on your expense budget for this week. What do you do?

options.text: Contact the supplier immediately to resolve the billing error and adjust your budget plan for the week to account for the mishap.
Accept the double billing and cut back on other kitchen expenses.
Ignore the error and continue operating as usual, hoping it balances out later.
Cancel orders for other ingredients to offset the mistake without informing staff.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Chef in charge of meal prep after the gaming team’s training sessions. Today, the team finished early, and meal service is now ahead of schedule. How do you adjust the kitchen’s workflow?

options.text: Reorganize tasks immediately to prioritize completing meal prep earlier, ensuring hot, fresh food is served when needed.
Maintain the original prep schedule despite the team’s training adjustment.
Rush all tasks at maximum speed to meet the adjusted timing without regard for quality.
Allow the team to wait while sticking strictly to your original timeline.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Chef reviewing your kitchen’s safety protocols after noticing some team members skipping basic hygiene steps. What do you do?

options.text: Hold a mandatory safety meeting to reinforce hygiene standards and regularly monitor compliance moving forward.
Issue warnings to those who are skipping hygiene steps without broader communication.
Ignore the issue, as it hasn’t caused any major problems yet.
Discipline the entire kitchen team to ensure compliance without addressing specifics.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Chef aiming to advance your career by networking within the gaming industry. A team manager asks you to cater their VIP networking event. How do you approach this opportunity?

options.text: Design an exceptional menu tailored to the VIP guests, showcasing your skills to build your reputation and connections.
Stick to your usual menu, as it’s reliable and requires no extra effort.
Decline the opportunity, citing a busy schedule in the kitchen.
Delegate the event entirely to your team without taking an active role.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Chef receiving praise from the gaming team for your nutritional meal planning. The team manager suggests you apply for an industry award recognizing chefs who work with athletes. What do you do?

options.text: Accept the suggestion, prepare documentation highlighting your achievements, and apply for the award to strengthen your career profile.
Politely decline the suggestion, preferring to focus solely on your current responsibilities.
Ignore the suggestion and wait for another opportunity in the future.
Ask the team manager to handle the application process entirely for you.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Chef considering enrolling in a professional certification program to improve your knowledge of sports nutrition. The program is expensive but could enhance your career prospects. What do you do?

options.text: Enroll in the certification program after evaluating the long-term career benefits and making adjustments to cover the cost.
Skip the certification to avoid the expense and continue with your current knowledge.
Ask your employer to pay for the certification without presenting clear evidence of its potential benefits.
Try to learn about sports nutrition through free online resources instead of pursuing certification.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Chef tasked with improving the profitability of your kitchen operations. You notice your team wastes a significant amount of food during prep. What do you do?

options.text: Train the team on proper portioning and implement systems to track and reduce food waste.
Ignore the food waste issue and focus on other aspects of kitchen operations.
Reduce ingredient orders drastically to prevent waste, even if it impacts menu variety.
Charge customers more to offset the cost of wasted food.

title: Head Coach - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Head Coach career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Esports Operations

questions.question_text: You are a Head Coach and one of your star players is struggling to communicate effectively with teammates during practice. The tension is starting to affect morale and gameplay. What do you do?

options.text: Facilitate a team meeting where everyone shares concerns and works on communication together.
Ignore the issue and hope the team resolves it on their own.
Criticize the player publicly to make them improve.
Switch the player to a less demanding role without addressing the issue.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Coach and two members of your esports team are in a heated argument over gameplay strategy right before a tournament. Both players are vital to the team’s success. What do you do?

options.text: Mediate the discussion and ensure both players have a chance to explain their perspective so the team can come to a unified decision.
Let them argue and expect them to resolve it themselves.
Side with the more experienced player and dismiss the other player's concerns.
Remove both players from the strategy planning process and handle it yourself.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Coach and notice the team's practice schedule is leading to burnout among players. Performance is declining, and the players seem frustrated. What do you do?

options.text: Revise the schedule to include rest days and mental health breaks to maintain peak performance.
Increase practice hours to push the players harder.
Leave the schedule as it is and tell players to adjust to the demands.
Focus only on gameplay strategy and not address the burnout issue.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Coach and the team is consistently underperforming in a specific game mode during scrimmages. The players feel frustrated and disengaged. What do you do?

options.text: Analyze gameplay footage and collaborate with players to develop targeted strategies for improvement.
Ignore the issue and focus on other game modes where the team is performing well.
Blame the players for poor execution without offering solutions.
Stop practicing this game mode entirely to avoid frustration.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Coach working with a limited budget for tournament travel expenses. The team wants premium accommodations, but you need to save costs. What do you do?

options.text: Book reasonable accommodations that balance comfort and cost, while explaining the budget constraints to the team.
Book the cheapest options regardless of how it affects player morale and focus.
Use the team’s prize money from previous tournaments to fund premium accommodations.
Let the players decide accommodations without considering the budget.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Coach and need to allocate funds between upgrading gaming equipment and hiring an additional analyst. Your current equipment is outdated, but the team’s analysis needs improvement. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the immediate needs of the team and prioritize upgrading equipment to improve gameplay performance.
Spend the entire budget on hiring an analyst and postpone equipment upgrades.
Split the budget equally without assessing what the team needs most.
Ignore both options and save the budget for future use.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Coach developing a new training protocol for the team to prepare for an upcoming tournament. The current system is outdated and inefficient. What do you do?

options.text: Design a clear, systematic training schedule incorporating analytics and player feedback to improve efficiency.
Stick with the outdated system to avoid disrupting the team’s routine.
Create a rigid schedule without consulting the players.
Let the players create their own training protocols individually.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Coach managing a high-pressure tournament schedule. The team has back-to-back matches, and you need to optimize their warm-up routine. What do you do?

options.text: Develop a short yet effective warm-up routine focused on communication and gameplay synchronization.
Skip the warm-up to save time and focus solely on game strategy.
Use the same lengthy warm-up routine regardless of time constraints and energy levels.
Let players decide their own warm-up routines without team coordination.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Coach and are invited to speak at a major esports conference. This could help grow your reputation and attract talent to your team. What do you do?

options.text: Accept the invitation and prepare a presentation highlighting your team’s success and coaching philosophy.
Decline the invitation to focus exclusively on team training.
Accept the invitation but do minimal preparation for the presentation.
Ignore the opportunity and let your assistant coach handle public appearances.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Coach and one of your former players is now a team manager of another esports organization. They offer to collaborate on strategies and share insights. What do you do?

options.text: Maintain a professional relationship and collaborate strategically to mutually improve team performance.
Refuse to collaborate out of fear they’ll gain competitive advantages.
Share all your strategies without any return expectations.
Ignore the offer and focus entirely on your own team.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Coach considering whether to spend extra time mentoring a junior player who shows potential but isn’t yet tournament-ready. What do you do?

options.text: Invest in one-on-one mentorship to help the player grow into a key contributor for future tournaments.
Focus your attention only on the senior players and leave the junior player to self-improve.
Ignore the junior player’s development until they prove themselves tournament-ready.
Replace the junior player with someone more experienced immediately.

questions.question_text: You are a Head Coach considering whether to enroll in a leadership certification program that costs money and time but could enhance your coaching skills. What do you do?

options.text: Enroll in the program, understanding the long-term value it will bring to your career and team leadership.
Skip the program to save money and avoid any short-term disruptions.
Enroll in the program and prioritize it over your current coaching responsibilities.
Wait to see if your organization will pay for the program before committing.

title: HR Manager - Career Exploration

questions.question_text: You are a HR Manager at a gaming company. One of your employees approaches you saying they feel undervalued because their manager is not recognizing their contributions. What do you do?

questions.question_text: You are a HR Manager planning to invest in professional development for your team. You find a certification program that aligns with company goals but is expensive. What do you do?

options.text: Pitch the certification program to leadership, showing its long-term ROI in improving team effectiveness.
Avoid the certification program due to its initial high cost.

questions.question_text: You are a gaming Influencer who has just received a negative comment from a long-time follower claiming that you ignored their question during your live stream. What do you do?

Switch immediately to the new platform without testing it first.
