Rush through the research and focus on writing to meet the deadline.
Request an extension without offering an alternative solution to meet the deadline.

questions.question_text: You are a Journalist tasked with interviewing multiple game developers in different locations. Due to a scheduling mix-up, two interviews have been double-booked. What do you do?

options.text: Reschedule one of the interviews and communicate clearly with both developers about the conflict.
Cancel one interview without notifying the developer.
Attempt to attend both interviews on the same day, even if it means rushing.
Skip both interviews and prioritize other tasks.

questions.question_text: You are a Journalist hoping to grow your career in gaming media. At a major gaming event, a networking opportunity arises to meet a famous game developer, but you are unsure how to approach them. What do you do?

options.text: Introduce yourself professionally, share your interest in their work, and exchange contact information.
Interrupt their conversation with others to introduce yourself.
Avoid approaching them because you're nervous about saying the wrong thing.
Wait for them to approach you instead of initiating contact.

questions.question_text: You are a Journalist who just completed a high-profile article that gained significant online traction. Your editor suggests pitching ideas for a follow-up piece to capitalize on the momentum. What do you do?

options.text: Brainstorm and pitch several relevant follow-up ideas to your editor.
Decline the suggestion and focus on your next unrelated assignment.
Ignore the momentum and assume readers won't be interested in a follow-up.
Work on the follow-up but without consulting your editor about the pitch.

questions.question_text: You are a Journalist offered a lucrative freelance contract to write promotional content for a gaming company. However, the contract stipulates that you cannot disclose the partnership in your articles. What do you do?

options.text: Decline the contract to maintain ethical integrity and transparency with your audience.
Accept the contract and write promotional content without disclosure.
Request that the gaming company remove the nondisclosure clause before accepting.
Accept the contract and disclose the partnership privately to your editor but not readers.

questions.question_text: You are a Journalist considering enrolling in an online gaming media course to improve your industry knowledge and boost your prospects. However, the course is expensive and time-intensive. What do you do?

options.text: Research the course content and evaluate its potential return on investment before enrolling.
Enroll immediately without reviewing the course details to avoid missing the opportunity.
Decide not to take the course because you prefer to learn through experience only.
Ignore the course but ask colleagues who have taken it to share their notes.

title: Lawyer - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Lawyer career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Legal & Compliance

questions.question_text: You are a Lawyer working in the gaming industry. A junior member of your legal team sends out an incomplete contract draft to a client without consulting you. The client is confused and upset. What do you do?

options.text: Take responsibility for the error, apologize to the client, clarify the situation, and work with the junior team member to fix the draft.
Criticize the junior member in front of the client to show accountability.
Ignore the client's concerns and focus only on fixing the draft internally.
Blame the junior member and ask the client to wait until the draft is corrected.

questions.question_text: You are a Lawyer at a gaming company. A colleague disagrees with your interpretation of a key clause in a licensing agreement, claiming it puts the company at risk. They propose an alternative interpretation that you believe to be incorrect. What do you do?

options.text: Schedule a meeting with your colleague to discuss both interpretations, backed by legal research, and propose involving a third-party expert if necessary.
Ignore their concern and proceed with your interpretation since you are more experienced.
Send an email to the team stating your interpretation without discussing the disagreement with your colleague.
Confront your colleague in a team meeting and insist your interpretation is correct without evidence.

questions.question_text: You are a Lawyer reviewing a licensing contract for a new gaming product. You notice ambiguous phrasing in the agreement that could lead to potential misinterpretation and disputes in the future. What do you do?

options.text: Flag the ambiguous clause, propose a clear revision, and discuss potential implications with the relevant teams before finalizing.
Assume the ambiguous clause won't cause issues and move forward without changing it.
Rewrite the entire contract without consulting the teams to ensure clarity.
Ignore the clause and prioritize other sections of the agreement that seem more critical.

questions.question_text: You are a Lawyer overseeing compliance for a gaming platform. During a routine review, you discover a new feature that may violate international data privacy laws. What do you do?

options.text: Immediately inform the development team, propose adjustments to ensure compliance, and conduct further research into the relevant laws.
Send a warning email to the team but allow the feature to launch while the issue is under review.
Delay the review process until the feature is launched and assess its impact afterward.
Conclude that the feature is acceptable since it complies with domestic laws.

questions.question_text: You are a Lawyer drafting a contract for a new gaming partnership. The partner asks for additional clauses that seem to favor them and could increase costs for your company without clear benefits. What do you do?

options.text: Negotiate with the partner to remove or modify the clauses, explaining their impact on costs and fairness.
Agree to the clauses to avoid conflict with the partner and finalize the agreement quickly.
Decline the partnership without negotiating further and inform your company of the decision.
Include the clauses but add vague language to make them harder to enforce.

questions.question_text: You are a Lawyer at a firm specializing in gaming law. A client disputes their bill, arguing that some charges for reviewing contracts are unfairly high. The client threatens to take their business elsewhere. What do you do?

options.text: Clarify the billing structure, offer to review the charges, and propose a compromise to maintain the relationship.
Ignore their complaint and insist the charges are standard without further explanation.
Reduce the bill significantly and apologize without investigating the dispute.
Refuse to negotiate and suggest they find another firm if they're unhappy.

questions.question_text: You are a Lawyer managing a gaming company's compliance processes. You need to submit legal filings for regulatory approval on a new product launch by the end of the week, but your team is behind schedule. What do you do?

options.text: Prioritize the legal filings, delegate specific tasks to team members, and work overtime to meet the deadline.
Delay the filings and communicate to stakeholders that the product launch may be postponed.
Submit incomplete filings to meet the deadline and plan to send updates later.
Assign the filings to a junior team member and move on to other tasks.

questions.question_text: You are a Lawyer reviewing internal compliance processes for a gaming platform. You realize that the procedures for handling customer data are outdated and may violate new privacy laws. What do you do?

options.text: Update the compliance procedures immediately based on current laws and ensure team members are trained on the new guidelines.
Continue using the outdated procedures until you receive explicit instructions to change them.
Ignore the issue for now and revisit the procedures during the next annual review.
Delegate the task of updating compliance procedures to a junior team member without providing guidance.

questions.question_text: You are a Lawyer at a gaming company and have the opportunity to attend a major industry conference where you could network with potential clients and establish new business relationships. However, the timing conflicts with a critical contract negotiation. What do you do?

options.text: Ask a trusted colleague to assist with the negotiation in your absence and attend the conference to network and grow the firm's client base.
Skip the conference to focus solely on the contract negotiation and avoid delegating responsibilities.
Attend the conference but ignore the contract negotiation entirely.
Cancel both the conference and negotiation, prioritizing internal administration tasks instead.

questions.question_text: You are a Lawyer trying to grow your client base in the gaming industry. A potential client expresses interest in your services but requests significant discounts that might affect your firm's profitability. What do you do?

options.text: Offer a small discount that aligns with your firm's pricing structure while highlighting the value your services provide.
Agree to the client's discount request to secure their business, regardless of its impact on profitability.
Decline the client's request and discourage further negotiations.
Agree to the discount and promise additional free services to please the client.

questions.question_text: You are a Lawyer at a gaming company specializing in intellectual property. A developer asks if they can use copyrighted material in a promotional trailer without purchasing rights, arguing that it would save money. What do you do?

options.text: Explain the legal risks and potential fines, recommend purchasing the rights, and suggest alternative materials that are royalty-free.
Approve the use of the copyrighted material since it is only for promotional purposes.
Recommend going ahead with the trailer and deal with any legal consequences later.
Suggest using copyrighted material without informing senior management.

questions.question_text: You are a Lawyer in charge of compliance for a gaming company. Your company is deciding whether to invest in an expensive legal training program to help employees stay updated on changing gaming regulations. The CEO asks for your recommendation. What do you do?

options.text: Advocate for the investment, highlighting the long-term benefits of regulatory compliance and reduced risks.
Recommend against the training program to save resources, suggesting that employees can learn on their own time.
Suggest postponing the decision until the next fiscal year to avoid immediate costs.
Advocate for outsourcing legal compliance instead of investing in employee training.

title: Lighting Tech - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Lighting Tech career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Broadcast & Production

questions.question_text: You are a Lighting Tech preparing for a live esports broadcast. Your team’s audio engineer is having trouble syncing their equipment with your lighting setup, and the broadcast goes live in 20 minutes. What do you do?

options.text: Collaborate with the audio engineer to troubleshoot the syncing issue and adjust your settings as needed.
Wait for the engineer to solve their issue while you continue working on unrelated lighting adjustments.
Escalate the issue to the director immediately without trying to solve it.
Ignore the problem since the lights appear to be working fine on your end.

questions.question_text: You are a Lighting Tech on a team setting up for a large gaming tournament. A new junior tech seems confused about how to operate a specific light panel they’ve been assigned. What do you do?

options.text: Take the time to explain the controls and help them adjust the light panel correctly.
Take over their task and finish it yourself to avoid delays.
Ask another teammate to handle the situation so you can focus on your own tasks.
Ignore the issue for now and wait until a break to address their confusion.

questions.question_text: You are a Lighting Tech designing a lighting rig for a new gaming studio. Midway through the planning, you notice that the lights you intended to use are back-ordered for two months. What do you do?

options.text: Research alternative lighting options that meet the studio’s specifications and propose them.
Delay the project until the back-ordered lights become available.
Use less powerful lights that are immediately available, even if they don’t meet specifications.
Ask the client to purchase the lights from a different supplier without offering alternative solutions.

questions.question_text: You are testing the lighting setup for a competitive gaming stream. Midway through the test, you notice a harsh glare on the players’ monitors caused by an overhead spotlight. What do you do?

options.text: Adjust the angle or intensity of the spotlight to eliminate the glare while maintaining the design.
Turn off the spotlight entirely to solve the issue quickly.
Ask the players to adjust their monitor positions instead of changing the lights.
Ignore the glare since the rest of the lighting works fine.

questions.question_text: You are a Lighting Tech working on a tight budget for a gaming tournament. You realize the lighting effect requested by the client will exceed the allocated budget. What do you do?

options.text: Discuss alternative effects with the client that fit within the budget.
Purchase the requested materials anyway and hope the client will cover the extra cost later.
Scale back the entire lighting setup to save costs elsewhere.
Ignore the budget and proceed as planned, prioritizing the client’s vision.

questions.question_text: You are bidding on a lighting project for a new esports studio. The client requests a detailed cost breakdown, but you realize you’ve underquoted for some high-end lights. What do you do?

options.text: Revise your bid and provide an updated cost breakdown, explaining the adjustments.
Stick to the original quote and absorb the extra costs yourself.
Submit the cost breakdown as-is and hope the client approves it.
Try to reduce costs elsewhere in the project without informing the client.

questions.question_text: You are a Lighting Tech on a team setting up a studio for an overnight live stream. The production schedule is running behind, and the producer asks you to skip the final lighting test to save time. What do you do?

options.text: Explain the importance of the test and suggest finding time elsewhere to stay on schedule.
Agree to skip the test to avoid further delays.
Do the test anyway without informing the producer, even if it causes more delays.
Agree to skip the test and ask the producer to take responsibility for any lighting issues.

questions.question_text: You are a Lighting Tech responsible for overseeing a setup crew. You notice a team member not following safety protocols while adjusting lighting fixtures high above the stage. What do you do?

options.text: Stop the work immediately and ensure the team member follows safety protocols.
Wait until the task is complete, then remind the team member about safety rules.
Report the safety violation to your supervisor and avoid confrontation.
Continue with your own tasks and assume they know what they’re doing.

questions.question_text: You’re a Lighting Tech at an esports production company and want to advance to lead designer. A senior colleague offers to mentor you, but it would require extra hours beyond your usual workweek. What do you do?

options.text: Accept the mentorship opportunity, as it will help you grow in your career.
Decline the mentorship to maintain work-life balance.
Ask for a promotion first before agreeing to extra hours.
Accept but only commit to mentorship during work hours.

questions.question_text: You are networking at a gaming industry event when you meet a potential new client who needs a Lighting Tech for an upcoming project. They ask for your portfolio on the spot. What do you do?

options.text: Share a digital portfolio you’ve prepared in advance.
Promise to email them your portfolio when you get back to work.
Give them your contact information and wait for them to follow up.
Explain that you don’t have a portfolio ready and suggest they check your social media.

questions.question_text: You are a Lighting Tech deciding whether to invest in an advanced lighting certification course. It’s expensive, but it could help you secure higher-paying projects. What do you do?

options.text: Enroll in the course, as it could improve your skills and career opportunities.
Skip the course and focus on gaining more on-the-job experience instead.
Wait for your employer to sponsor the course before committing.
Take the course only if it’s free or heavily discounted.

questions.question_text: You’re offered a freelance opportunity to design lighting for a small gaming event, but the pay is below industry standards. What do you do?

options.text: Negotiate a better rate by emphasizing your expertise and experience.
Accept the job as-is to gain experience and build your portfolio.
Decline the job because the pay isn’t worth your time.
Take the job and try to complete it quickly to minimize your effort.

title: Performance Coach - Career Exploration

subject: Health & Wellness

questions.question_text: You are a Performance Coach working with a professional esports team. A player approaches you, frustrated because they feel they're not receiving enough feedback from the coaching staff, which is affecting their performance. What do you do?

options.text: Schedule a one-on-one session to discuss their concerns and collaborate on a feedback strategy.
Tell them to wait until the next team meeting to bring up their concerns.
Explain that feedback is given equally to all players and they need to adapt to the existing system.

questions.question_text: You are a Performance Coach for an esports team. During a team workshop, two players begin arguing about game strategies, disrupting the session. What do you do?

options.text: Calmly intervene and mediate the argument to find common ground while refocusing the group.
Allow the argument to continue, hoping they’ll resolve it on their own.
End the workshop early and confront the players individually later.
Ignore the argument and continue the workshop despite the disruption.

questions.question_text: You are a Performance Coach tasked with developing mental resilience exercises for a player who struggles under pressure during tournaments. What do you do?

options.text: Design a personalized mental skills training program focused on visualization and breathing techniques.
Recommend general online resources and tell them to explore on their own.
Suggest increasing their physical training intensity to build resilience.
Advise them to take a break from competitive play without providing additional guidance.

questions.question_text: You are a Performance Coach implementing a new reaction-time training tool for the team's players. One player says the tool is ineffective and refuses to participate. What do you do?

options.text: Have a private discussion with the player to understand their concerns and adapt the tool if needed.
Ignore their refusal and focus on players who are participating.
Tell the player they must use the tool as it’s part of the program requirements.
Remove the tool from the program entirely to avoid further resistance.

questions.question_text: You are a Performance Coach and your department has been given a limited budget for the season. You need to plan a mental skills workshop but have to cut costs. What do you do?

options.text: Find free or low-cost resources and focus on delivering valuable content using existing materials.
Drop the workshop entirely to save money for other priorities.
Ask players to contribute their own funds to cover costs.
Book expensive resources and hope other departments can cover the cost later.

questions.question_text: You are a Performance Coach working remotely with multiple clients. One of your clients asks for a discounted rate for your services, but offering discounts would exceed your budget constraints. What do you do?

options.text: Politely explain that your rates are fixed and highlight the value of your services.
Agree to the discount and hope you can cover the budget gap later.
Offer them a free session to make up for not lowering your rates.
Ignore their request and avoid discussing pricing further.

questions.question_text: You are a Performance Coach and the team manager wants a report detailing players' progress over the past month. You have limited time due to other priorities. What do you do?

options.text: Create a concise report summarizing key metrics and insights for efficiency.
Skip the report and focus on your coaching tasks instead.
Ask the manager for an extension without attempting to start the report.
Provide raw data to the manager instead of summarizing progress.

questions.question_text: You are a Performance Coach and notice that the team's pre-game routine often runs over the scheduled time, delaying warmups. How do you address this issue?

options.text: Streamline the routine by cutting unnecessary steps and communicating the importance of time management to players.
Let the routine continue as is and adjust warmup schedules accordingly.
Skip the routine entirely to avoid delays in the future.
Run multiple routines simultaneously with no adjustments to timing.

questions.question_text: You are a Performance Coach seeking to grow your career by networking. You are invited to a major esports industry event but have limited time due to client commitments. What do you do?

options.text: Prioritize attending the event and reschedule client sessions to accommodate your career growth.
Decline the event to focus entirely on your current clients.
Attend the event but avoid actively networking to save time.
Send someone else in your place to represent your coaching services.

questions.question_text: You are a Performance Coach and one of your players has recommended you to another team’s management for a workshop. Accepting the offer would provide strong career exposure, but you’re already at full capacity with your current team. What do you do?

options.text: Propose a partnership agreement that allows you to conduct the workshop while balancing your current commitments.
Reject the offer to prioritize your current workload.
Accept the offer immediately without considering the impact on your current clients.
Accept the offer and delegate your current responsibilities to others.

questions.question_text: You are a Performance Coach considering pursuing a specialized certification in esports psychology. The program is expensive and will require significant time investment but could increase your earning potential. What do you do?

options.text: Discuss the potential benefits with mentors and assess if the certification aligns with your career goals.
Decide not to pursue the certification to save money.
Immediately enroll without reviewing how it fits into your career plan.

questions.question_text: You are a Performance Coach and a competing team offers to hire you for a higher salary but asks you to share exclusive training strategies you developed. What do you do?

options.text: Decline the offer and maintain the integrity of your role with your current team.
Accept the offer and share the strategies, considering it a good career move.
Negotiate the offer so you don’t have to share the strategies but still take the job.

title: Photographer - Career Exploration

subject: Creative & Media

questions.question_text: You are a Photographer working on a gaming event shoot. A team member assisting with lighting is not setting up the equipment according to your instructions, impacting your timeline. What do you do?

options.text: Politely pull the team member aside, explain the importance of following the setup plan, and offer assistance if needed.

options.text: Respectfully share your professional perspective and suggest an alternative pose that achieves their goal.
Completely disregard their request and shoot the pose you feel is better without explaining.

questions.question_text: You are a Photographer shooting product photos for a new gaming console. During the shoot, the camera you are using starts malfunctioning, causing delays. What do you do?

options.text: Switch to your backup camera and continue the shoot seamlessly.
Try to repair the camera on-site, even though you’re not sure how to fix it.
Cancel the shoot and inform the client you’ll reschedule after getting the camera repaired.

questions.question_text: You are tasked with editing the photos from a recent gaming event. A client has requested a vibrant and colorful style, but your photo editing software's presets are producing washed-out results. What do you do?

options.text: Manually adjust the color settings and lighting in the software to achieve the desired look.
Settle for the washed-out preset and submit the photos as is.

questions.question_text: You are a Photographer preparing a budget for a gaming company's promotional campaign. The client has given you a fixed budget, but the cost of renting top-tier equipment exceeds it. What do you do?

options.text: Identify alternatives, such as renting mid-tier equipment, to stay within the budget while maintaining quality.
Charge the client extra for the equipment, even though it exceeds their budget.
Use your personal savings to cover the extra equipment costs.
Cancel the project and inform the client their budget is insufficient.

questions.question_text: You are discussing pricing with a potential client for shooting a gaming event. The client offers to pay less than your standard rate, promising future collaborations. What do you do?

options.text: Politely decline the offer and explain the value of your standard rate.
Accept the lower rate without negotiation in the hopes of future work.
Respond angrily and refuse to work with the client altogether.
Offer to work for free this time to ensure future collaborations.

questions.question_text: You are a Photographer covering a gaming convention, and the event organizers provide a detailed shot list. Halfway through the event, you realize you're falling behind schedule. What do you do?

options.text: Reprioritize the shot list to focus on the most important shots within the remaining time.
Abandon the shot list entirely and take random photos instead.
Focus on catching up by rushing through all the remaining shots, compromising quality.
Stick to the original plan, even if you can’t complete the shot list.

questions.question_text: You are a Photographer editing a large number of gaming photos with a tight deadline. Your current editing workflow is taking too long, and you're at risk of missing the deadline. What do you do?

options.text: Use batch editing tools and focus manual edits on the most important photos.
Skip the editing process altogether and submit unedited photos.
Request an extension on the deadline without trying to improve efficiency.

questions.question_text: You are a Photographer aiming to grow your client base in the gaming industry. A key decision-maker from a major gaming company attends your event shoot. How do you approach them?

options.text: Introduce yourself professionally, mention your expertise, and hand them your business card.
Ignore them, assuming they will reach out if they like your work.
Approach them casually and try to engage in small talk without mentioning your work.
Ask them immediately if they’ll hire you for future projects.

questions.question_text: You are a Photographer with an opportunity to collaborate on a feature for a major gaming publication, but they require a portfolio showcasing similar work. Your portfolio is outdated. What do you do?

options.text: Quickly update your portfolio with relevant recent work before submitting it.
Submit your outdated portfolio and hope it’s sufficient.
Decline the opportunity because you don’t have an updated portfolio.
Borrow photos from another photographer to supplement your portfolio.

questions.question_text: You are a Photographer considering whether to invest in a new certification in advanced photo editing. The course is expensive but could attract higher-paying gaming clients. What do you do?

options.text: Invest in the certification, knowing it could pay off in the long term.
Decide against the certification because it’s too expensive upfront.
Enroll in the course without considering its relevance to your career goals.
Ask your clients to pay for the certification before deciding whether to enroll.

questions.question_text: You are a Photographer offered a lucrative project that requires extensive post-production editing. However, the client insists on a turnaround time you know is unfeasible without sacrificing quality. What do you do?

options.text: Negotiate a more realistic timeline that allows you to maintain quality.
Accept the project and sacrifice quality to meet their timeline.
Decline the project entirely because the timeline is impossible.

title: Product Manager - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Product Manager career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Business & Technology

questions.question_text: You are a Product Manager overseeing a team developing a new level for a popular game. One of your designers is consistently submitting work late, which is delaying the team's progress. What do you do?

options.text: Schedule a private meeting with the designer to understand the root cause of the delays and offer support.
Publicly address the issue in front of the team during your next stand-up meeting.
Assign the designer's tasks to another team member without discussing the issue.
Ignore the delays, assuming the designer will resolve the issue on their own.

questions.question_text: You are a Product Manager, and your team is struggling to align on the creative direction of a new game feature. Tensions are high in your meeting, with team members talking over one another. What do you do?

options.text: Pause the discussion, set rules for turn-taking, and facilitate a focused brainstorming session.
Allow the team to continue debating until they reach a resolution naturally.
Choose the idea you like best and instruct the team to follow it.
End the meeting and ask the team to sort it out on their own time.

questions.question_text: You are a Product Manager and players have reported a significant number of bugs in a new feature that was just launched. What do you do?

Postpone fixing the bugs until you release the next major game update.

questions.question_text: You are a Product Manager for a gaming company and one of your competitors has just launched a similar feature to one you're developing. Your team feels demotivated. What do you do?

options.text: Analyze the competitor's feature, identify areas where your product can excel, and refocus the team on delivering unique value.
Halt development of your feature entirely to avoid competition.

Rush the release of your feature without testing to beat the competitor to market.

questions.question_text: You are a Product Manager working on budgeting for your next game update. The team proposes adding an extra feature that will exceed your budget by 20%. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the feature's potential ROI and consult stakeholders before deciding whether to allocate additional budget.
Approve the additional cost immediately without further discussion.
Reject the feature outright to avoid going over budget.
Reduce the quality of other features to make room for the new addition.

questions.question_text: You are a Product Manager setting the price for a new downloadable content (DLC) pack for your company's game. Your team suggests a price that you believe is too high for your target audience. What do you do?

options.text: Request market research to understand what price point would maximize sales without alienating players.
Set the high price your team suggested to maximize profits.
Choose the lowest price possible to ensure all players can afford it.
Launch the DLC for free to attract more players to your game.

questions.question_text: You are a Product Manager organizing a weekly sprint planning meeting. The team is deviating from the planned agenda and discussing unrelated topics, which puts you behind schedule. What do you do?

options.text: Refocus the team by reminding them of the agenda and steering the conversation back to planned topics.
End the meeting early since it has gone off track.
Let the team continue the discussion, hoping it will naturally return to the agenda.
Cancel the meeting and reschedule it for another time.

questions.question_text: You are a Product Manager, and your team is falling behind on a critical milestone for a new feature launch. You suspect the issue is due to inefficient workflows. What do you do?

options.text: Analyze the team's current workflows and identify areas where processes can be optimized.
Ask the team to work overtime until the milestone is met.
Extend the milestone deadline without addressing the underlying issues.
Reassign tasks randomly to test if efficiency improves.

questions.question_text: You are a Product Manager and have been asked to present a major success of your game at an industry conference. This is a great networking opportunity, but it conflicts with another important project deadline. What do you do?

options.text: Delegate project responsibilities to your team while you attend the conference and represent your company.
Cancel your conference appearance to focus on the project.
Attempt to do both, splitting your time between the conference and the project.

questions.question_text: You are a Product Manager and have just received an email from a well-known industry professional complimenting your latest game update. They invite you to connect at an upcoming networking event. What do you do?

options.text: Respond to the email, accept the invitation, and prepare to discuss your work at the event.
Ignore the email, assuming it isn’t a high-priority task.
Forward the email to your boss and ask them to respond on your behalf.
Decline the invitation because you’re busy with other tasks.

questions.question_text: You are a Product Manager and discover that a vendor you work with frequently is offering to expedite your project in exchange for an additional fee. You know your budget is tight, but the expedited timeline could boost early sales. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the cost versus the potential revenue impact of launching early before making a decision.
Decline the offer without analyzing the potential benefits.
Agree to pay the fee immediately to expedite the project.
Ask the vendor to do it for free to maintain your timeline.

questions.question_text: You are a Product Manager and are considering enrolling in a professional certification course to enhance your skills in roadmap planning. The course is expensive and will take time away from your current projects. What do you do?

options.text: Discuss with your supervisor to ensure alignment with company goals and seek support for the certification.
Pay for the course yourself and focus on it during work hours.
Skip the certification because it’s too expensive.

title: Production Manager - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Production Manager career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Broadcast & Production

questions.question_text: You are a Production Manager overseeing a large team preparing for a live eSports broadcast. Two of your key team members are having a heated argument about the division of responsibilities, and it’s affecting the morale of the group. What do you do?

options.text: Call both team members aside privately, mediate the issue, and help them clarify their roles and responsibilities.
Publicly reprimand both team members to show that such behavior is unacceptable.

Abandon storytelling altogether since the budget is too limited.

questions.question_text: You are a Scriptwriter working on a horror game with limited audio resources. The producer wants you to write a scene requiring multiple unique sound effects, but these will exceed the budget. What do you do?

options.text: Adjust the scene to use fewer sound effects while maintaining the tension and horror elements.
Convince the producer to exceed the budget since the scene is crucial to the game’s quality.
Ignore the budget limitations and write the scene with all the requested sound effects.
Remove the scene entirely to avoid dealing with audio resource constraints.

questions.question_text: You are a Scriptwriter on a team for a big game release. The project manager assigns you a strict two-day deadline to complete the story for a side quest. However, you also need to collaborate with the environment designers to match the setting of the quest. How do you manage your time?

options.text: Schedule a quick meeting with the environment designers to ensure the setting aligns with your story before drafting the quest.
Write the story without consulting the environment designers to save time and meet the deadline.
Focus only on the story writing and leave setting alignment to the designers.
Ask for an extension because collaboration will take too much time.

questions.question_text: You are a Scriptwriter revising your game’s main story arc. The timeline spreadsheet shows you are behind schedule, and the studio is pressuring the team to meet the final deadline. How do you ensure timely completion?

options.text: Prioritize the most crucial story elements and focus on finishing them by the deadline.
Rush through the remaining writing to meet the timeline, sacrificing quality.
Wait for the studio to extend the deadline since they are aware of the delays.
Ask for additional team members to help write the story without adjusting your workflow.

questions.question_text: You are a Scriptwriter trying to build your reputation in the gaming industry. An opportunity arises to pitch a story idea to a well-known studio, but you have limited personal connections there. How do you proceed?

options.text: Research the studio’s past projects and tailor your pitch to align with their style and audience.
Submit a generic pitch without considering the studio’s prior work.
Reach out to someone you vaguely know at the studio and ask them to recommend your pitch.
Wait for a more established connection to help you get noticed.

questions.question_text: You are a Scriptwriter and your studio offers you an opportunity to work on a high-profile game. Accepting the role would mean longer work hours and less time for personal projects. What do you do?

options.text: Accept the role to grow your career and gain recognition, while managing your schedule carefully.
Decline the role to maintain work-life balance and focus on your personal projects.
Accept the role but prioritize your personal projects over the high-profile game.
Ask the studio to change the work hours before accepting the role.

questions.question_text: You are a Scriptwriter and a studio requests a fantasy story that includes themes of betrayal and redemption. You realize that one subplot might depict a sensitive topic in a way that could offend players. How do you address this?

options.text: Revise the subplot to maintain the theme while avoiding content that could be harmful or offensive.
Leave the subplot as is, trusting that players will understand your creative intent.
Remove the subplot entirely to avoid any controversy.
Ask for feedback after the release to determine if the subplot requires changes.

questions.question_text: You are a Scriptwriter and a junior colleague asks for advice on improving their story draft. They are using outdated narrative techniques that are unlikely to resonate with modern players. What do you do?

options.text: Explain the importance of modern storytelling trends and recommend resources for improvement.
Re-write their draft for them without further explanation.
Compliment their draft and avoid providing constructive criticism to avoid upsetting them.
Tell them their work is outdated and ask them to try again on their own.

title: Social Media Manager - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Social Media Manager career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Marketing & Community

questions.question_text: You are a Social Media Manager for a gaming company, and a team member in charge of designing graphics for a major campaign has suddenly fallen ill just two days before launch. What do you do?

options.text: Collaborate with the rest of the team to divide the work and meet the deadline.
Postpone the campaign until the designer recovers to maintain quality.
Try to create the graphics yourself even though it’s not your area of expertise.
Let the project manager know and leave the responsibility entirely to them.

questions.question_text: You notice a heated argument between two team members regarding the creative direction of a major social media campaign for a new game launch. The deadline is tight. What do you do?

options.text: Step in as a mediator to facilitate productive conversation and help them reach a compromise.
Side with the team member who has more experience to resolve issues faster.
Let the argument run its course and focus on your own tasks until they resolve it.
Escalate the issue to your manager immediately without attempting to resolve it yourself.

questions.question_text: You are reviewing the content calendar for next month’s campaign promoting a new game. A video scheduled to be released has low production quality and doesn’t align with brand guidelines. What do you do?

options.text: Request a redo of the video, even if it means delaying the campaign slightly.
Approve the video since the campaign launch date is more important than quality.
Publish the video as planned but release an edited version later.
Replace the video with an older, higher-quality asset that isn’t fully aligned with the campaign.

questions.question_text: You notice that your competitors' social media posts are performing better because of innovative 3D animations, which your company doesn’t use. Your manager asks for suggestions to keep up. What do you propose?

options.text: Recommend investing in 3D animation software and training to create similar content.
Replicate your competitors’ posts exactly to save time and effort.
Stick to the current format since it has worked in the past.
Stop focusing on competitors and just increase the frequency of your current posts.

questions.question_text: You’ve been given a limited budget to promote your company’s new game on social media. How do you allocate the funds?

options.text: Focus on platforms where your target audience is most active, even if it means spending less on other platforms.
Spread the budget evenly across all platforms to ensure balanced visibility.
Spend the entire budget on one platform to make the biggest splash.
Let your manager decide how to allocate the budget since it’s their responsibility.

questions.question_text: You’re running a paid ad campaign for a new game, but halfway through the campaign, you realize that the cost-per-click (CPC) is much higher than expected, putting the campaign over budget. What do you do?

options.text: Pause the campaign, analyze the data, and adjust the targeting to lower CPC.
Continue the campaign as planned because the budget will balance out in the long run.
Switch to promoting a different game without notifying your team.
Increase the campaign’s budget to ensure it continues running without optimizing.

questions.question_text: You discover that your current editorial process is taking too long, causing delays in posting updates about your gaming community. How do you address it?

options.text: Streamline the approval process by reducing redundant steps and automating where possible.
Skip the approval process to make sure posts are published on time.
Ask for a larger team to manage the workload.
Reduce the number of posts to match your current timeline capabilities.

questions.question_text: Your manager assigns you to schedule and post content for a game launch happening in two weeks. Several other campaigns are already in progress, making your schedule tight. How do you plan your workflow?

options.text: Prioritize and space out the campaigns in the calendar, ensuring nothing is overlooked.
Focus solely on the game launch and pause the other campaigns temporarily.
Work overtime without notifying anyone to complete all tasks by yourself.
Delegate the less important campaigns to the interns without supervision.

questions.question_text: A popular gaming influencer reaches out to you directly to collaborate on promoting your latest title. How do you handle the situation?

options.text: Engage with the influencer, review their past work, and pitch a collaboration proposal to your manager.
Ignore the influencer and stick to your usual marketing plan.
Offer the influencer free products in exchange for promotion without consulting your team.
Ask the influencer to send their plan but don’t follow up.

questions.question_text: Your company’s CEO has asked you to build relationships with gaming communities to increase trust and engagement. What is your best approach?

options.text: Host live Q&A sessions with game developers to engage directly with the community.
Focus solely on paid promotions to grow the community quickly.
Reach out to multiple communities with generic messages to save time.
Wait for community members to reach out to your company first.

questions.question_text: You notice that one of your social media posts includes incorrect pricing for an exclusive gaming package. It has already garnered significant engagement. What do you do?

options.text: Immediately edit or take down the post and address the pricing error transparently with your audience.
Leave the post up since it has high engagement and deal with refund issues later.
Ignore the issue and hope nobody notices the discrepancy.
Blame the error on a team member in public to avoid criticism.

questions.question_text: You’re considering pursuing a certification in advanced analytics and reporting to enhance your skills as a Social Media Manager. However, the certification is costly, and you’ll need to manage your work and study time carefully. What do you do?

options.text: Assess how the certification aligns with your career goals and pursue it if the ROI is justified.
Skip the certification and focus only on your current job responsibilities.
Enroll in the certification immediately, even if you’re too busy to focus on it.
Wait for your employer to ask you to complete the certification before committing.

title: Software Engineer - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Software Engineer career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Technology

questions.question_text: You are a Software Engineer working on a team to develop a new multiplayer gaming feature. One of your teammates has proposed a solution that you believe could lead to performance issues during peak usage. What do you do?

options.text: Respectfully explain your concerns and suggest alternatives based on data.
Ignore the proposal and focus on your own tasks.
Agree with the proposal to avoid conflict in the team.
Escalate the issue to your manager without discussing it with your teammate.

questions.question_text: You are a Software Engineer leading a weekly team meeting to discuss project progress. One of your colleagues consistently interrupts others and dominates the conversation. The team seems frustrated but hesitant to speak up. What do you do?

options.text: Politely intervene and remind everyone to ensure all voices are heard during the meeting.
Let the colleague continue speaking to avoid confrontation.
End the meeting early and discuss the issue privately later.
Ignore the situation and continue with the meeting agenda.

questions.question_text: You are a Software Engineer tasked with fixing a bug in the gaming application. The issue is causing players' profiles to reset unexpectedly. There is pressure to resolve it quickly because players are complaining online. What do you do?

options.text: Analyze the code thoroughly to identify the root cause before applying a fix.
Make a quick fix without testing it to resolve the issue as soon as possible.
Ask the customer service team to reassure players while you delay working on the bug.
Suggest rolling back to a previous version without investigating the bug.

questions.question_text: You are working on a new game feature that will allow players to customize their avatars. A teammate has proposed using a new 3D rendering library they discovered, but you are unfamiliar with it. What do you do?

options.text: Take time to research the library and determine its compatibility with your existing codebase.
Reject the proposal since you are unfamiliar with the library and prefer to use what you already know.
Approve the library without researching it to save time.
Ask the teammate to handle the feature development alone.

questions.question_text: You are a Software Engineer asked to provide a cost estimate for upgrading your company's game servers to handle a 50% increase in player traffic. The finance team has requested this information before approving the upgrade. What do you do?

options.text: Research server costs and provide an estimate based on current and projected traffic data.
Provide a rough estimate without researching server specifications and costs.
Suggest an arbitrary budget that seems large enough to cover the upgrade without calculating details.
Recommend delaying the decision until other priorities are addressed.

questions.question_text: Your team has exceeded the budget allocated for developing a new game feature, and the project manager asks you to find ways to cut costs while still meeting deadlines. How do you respond?

options.text: Propose simplifying non-essential features to reduce development time and costs.
Suggest cutting corners in testing to save time and money.
Advise the manager to abandon the project entirely due to budget constraints.
Suggest delaying the feature rollout indefinitely.

questions.question_text: You are a Software Engineer managing multiple tasks, including debugging code, attending team meetings, and designing new features. A new deadline is approaching, and one task is falling behind schedule. What do you do?

options.text: Prioritize the most urgent tasks and communicate the delay with your team and manager.
Focus entirely on the delayed task and ignore other responsibilities for now.
Work overtime on all tasks without notifying your team.
Skip the delayed task entirely to meet the deadline for other deliverables.

questions.question_text: You discover that your team has been using an outdated workflow for version control that is causing code conflicts. What do you do?

options.text: Recommend switching to a modern version control tool and provide training to the team.
Ignore the issue since switching tools would require effort and delay the current project.
Let the team continue using the outdated tool while making your own adjustments.
Ask the manager to handle the decision without providing input.

questions.question_text: You are a Software Engineer hoping to advance your career by taking on additional responsibilities in your current gaming company. Your manager has invited you to lead a major project, but it will require significant extra hours. What do you do?

options.text: Accept the opportunity and work with your manager to balance the additional workload.
Decline the opportunity because you are concerned about working extra hours.
Accept the project without discussing workload management, hoping you can handle it.
Suggest that your colleague take the lead and continue your current responsibilities.

questions.question_text: You are a Software Engineer attending a conference where you meet an executive from a major gaming company. They express interest in your work and hint at future job opportunities. How do you respond?

options.text: Engage professionally, exchange contact information, and follow up later to discuss opportunities.
Immediately ask for a job and pressure the executive for a decision.
Dismiss the conversation and focus on your current role.
Criticize your current company to gain sympathy from the executive.

questions.question_text: Your manager asks you to integrate third-party analytics software into the gaming platform to track user behavior. The software has good reviews but requires sensitive player data. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the software's privacy policies and ensure compliance with player data protection standards before integration.
Integrate the software immediately to meet the manager's request without reviewing privacy concerns.
Refuse to use the software based on the fact that it is third-party, without further investigation.
Delay the integration indefinitely to avoid responsibility for data issues.

questions.question_text: You are considering investing in a certification program that will improve your skills in cloud computing for gaming applications. It is expensive and will require time outside of work to complete. What do you do?

options.text: Evaluate the certification's relevance to your career goals and ROI before deciding to pursue it.
Sign up for the certification immediately without considering its benefits or costs.
Ignore the certification because it requires extra time and money.
Postpone the decision indefinitely to avoid commitment.

title: Sound Engineer - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Sound Engineer career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Broadcast & Production

questions.question_text: You are a Sound Engineer working with a team on a live gaming event. During setup, you notice the microphone levels are inconsistent between the hosts on stage, causing frustration. One team member insists it's fine, but you know it will impact the audience experience. What do you do?

options.text: Calmly communicate the importance of balanced audio and offer to adjust the levels yourself.
Ignore the issue since a team member said it was fine and focus on other tasks.
Raise your voice to insist the team member address the issue immediately.
Wait and address the issue during the event if it becomes noticeable.

questions.question_text: You are a Sound Engineer overseeing an online multiplayer game audio session. A junior colleague keeps adjusting the mix levels incorrectly, making the sound effects overpower the dialogue. The deadline is tight, and they seem stressed. What do you do?

options.text: Step in to re-balance the mix and offer constructive feedback to help them improve.
Let them keep working and avoid saying anything to prevent further stress.
Take over their responsibility without explaining why, ensuring the audio meets the deadline.
Ignore the issue and focus on other parts of the sound design.

questions.question_text: You are a Sound Engineer reviewing the final audio mix for a trailer of a new video game. You notice subtle distortions in the bass frequency that could affect audio quality when played on low-end speakers. What do you do?

options.text: Revisit the bass frequency settings and tweak the mix to ensure compatibility with all speaker types.
Assume most players will use high-quality headphones and leave the bass as it is.
Reduce all bass levels drastically to solve the distortion problem quickly.
Release the trailer as is to meet the deadline without informing the team about the distortion.

questions.question_text: You are a Sound Engineer configuring audio equipment for a high-tech gaming conference. The soundboard is malfunctioning due to outdated firmware, and no backup system is available. What do you do?

options.text: Quickly update the firmware, test the equipment, and inform the team about the delay.
Switch to manual audio controls and hope they work until the firmware issues resolve.
Ignore the firmware problem and proceed with setup, hoping it doesn’t affect the event.
Cancel the event setup and report the issue without exploring solutions.

questions.question_text: You are a Sound Engineer managing audio for a small gaming studio with a limited budget. The studio director wants to use expensive audio plugins that exceed the budget for the current project. What do you do?

options.text: Suggest alternative, cost-effective plugins that deliver similar results within budget.
Purchase the expensive plugins and ask the studio director for additional funding later.
Use free plugins without discussing their limitations with the studio director.
Request the studio director cut costs elsewhere to afford the expensive plugins.

questions.question_text: You are a Sound Engineer preparing a budget proposal for equipment upgrades at a gaming venue. The venue manager requests additional features that weren’t originally scoped within the budget. What do you do?

options.text: Provide a revised budget with cost estimates for the additional features and their impact on the project timeline.
Agree to include the new features without adjusting the budget, assuming costs will be covered later.
Reject the request and proceed with the original budget proposal to avoid complications.
Offer to remove other planned upgrades to accommodate the new features within the budget.

questions.question_text: You are a Sound Engineer planning the workflow for mixing and mastering audio for a new first-person shooter game. Halfway through the mix, your software crashes due to unsaved files. What do you do?

options.text: Reopen the software and start from the last saved version, while implementing regular auto-save settings.
Restart the mix from scratch and hope to meet the deadline without implementing changes to your workflow.
Switch to a completely new software and redo the mix, even if it delays the project.
Ask your manager for an extension while you rebuild the mix from memory.

questions.question_text: You are a Sound Engineer supervising an online recording session for game voice-over artists. The recording software license expires mid-session, which prevents further progress. What do you do?

options.text: Pause the session, renew the license immediately, and resume the recording to avoid quality issues.
Continue recording without the software, using unapproved alternatives and focus on fixing issues later.
Cancel the session and request the artists to reschedule for another day.
Ask the artists to record their parts independently and send files for editing later.

questions.question_text: You are a Sound Engineer aiming to build your reputation in the gaming industry. A popular studio invites you to present a showcase of your audio design work at an upcoming gaming conference. What do you do?

options.text: Accept the invitation, prepare a detailed and engaging showcase, and network with industry professionals.
Decline the invitation, as preparing the showcase would distract you from current projects.
Accept the invitation, but prepare a rush job presentation to save time.
Request payment for presenting your showcase without focusing on networking opportunities.

questions.question_text: You are a Sound Engineer applying for a senior position at a gaming production company. During the interview, you are asked about how you’ve contributed to project revenue in your previous roles. What do you do?

options.text: Highlight your contributions to audio quality that improved user experience and positively impacted sales.
State that your focus is purely on technical audio work and avoid discussing revenue impacts.
Mention unrelated technical skills to demonstrate your expertise but avoid discussing revenue contributions.
Explain that revenue generation is solely the responsibility of marketing, not sound engineering.

questions.question_text: You are a Sound Engineer considering further education to stay competitive in the industry. A specialized certification in immersive sound design costs $4,000 but could lead to higher-paying roles. What do you do?

options.text: Invest in the certification, knowing it could advance your career and increase earnings.
Avoid the certification and focus on gaining experience without spending money.
Ask your employer to pay for the certification without committing to use the skills in your current role.
Take free online courses instead to save money, even if they lack certification recognition.

questions.question_text: You are a Sound Engineer working on a tight deadline for a gaming company. A competitor offers you a higher-paying role but requires you to leave your current project unfinished. What do you do?

options.text: Complete your current project before accepting or rejecting the new role to maintain professional integrity.
Accept the new role immediately and leave your current company without notice.
Ask for a raise from your current employer to counter the competitor’s offer.
Reject the competitor’s offer without considering your long-term career goals.

title: Sponsorship Coordinator - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Sponsorship Coordinator career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Business & Finance

questions.question_text: You are a Sponsorship Coordinator and notice that one of your team members seems disengaged during meetings about securing a major sponsor. This person has been a top performer in the past but hasn't contributed much lately. What do you do?

options.text: Schedule a one-on-one meeting with the team member to understand their concerns and offer support.
Ignore the situation and hope they start contributing again on their own.
Confront them during the next meeting and ask why they're not participating.
Assign them a minor task and assume they’ll improve.

questions.question_text: You are a Sponsorship Coordinator attending a networking event where you meet a potential sponsor who is unfamiliar with your company. They begin asking questions about your organization's gaming platform and reach. What do you do?

options.text: Clearly explain your platform, its audience, and how partnering with your company can meet their goals.
Hand over your business card and suggest they check the website for details.
Focus on talking about your team's achievements without giving much detail about the platform.
Change the subject to avoid answering questions you’re unsure about.

questions.question_text: You are a Sponsorship Coordinator preparing promotional materials for a gaming tournament. While reviewing drafts, you notice the sponsor's logo is outdated and does not match their branding guidelines. What do you do?

options.text: Contact the sponsor immediately to request the correct version of their logo and update the materials.
Use the logo provided and assume it’s fine since the sponsor hasn’t mentioned it.
Decide to remove the sponsor’s logo from the materials to avoid using the wrong version.
Continue with the outdated logo and hope the sponsor doesn’t notice.

questions.question_text: You are a Sponsorship Coordinator tasked with creating a pitch deck for a new gaming sponsorship deal. The team has shared a generic template, but some slides feel outdated and irrelevant to the client. What do you do?

options.text: Tailor the pitch deck to the client by updating the slides to reflect their industry and specific goals.
Use the generic template without any modifications, focusing on speed over customization.
Request another generic deck from the team and hope it’s more relevant.
Delay the pitch meeting until you have time to create an entirely new deck from scratch.

questions.question_text: You are a Sponsorship Coordinator negotiating a partnership deal with a sponsor who is requesting a lower price for exclusive branding opportunities during a gaming event. Lowering the price would impact your team's budget but might secure the deal. What do you do?

options.text: Offer a reduced price with adjustments to the scope of the branding opportunities to meet both parties’ needs.
Agree to the lower price without any changes to the branding opportunities to secure the deal.
Refuse the lower price and insist on the original pricing, risking the deal.
Accept their offer but reduce the event’s overall budget by cutting unrelated expenses.

questions.question_text: You are a Sponsorship Coordinator reviewing the budget allocation for a new gaming sponsorship campaign. You realize the amount dedicated to promotional materials is higher than expected, leaving less for live event branding. What do you do?

options.text: Reallocate funds to ensure both promotional materials and live event branding receive adequate support.
Stick to the original budget allocation and focus only on promotional materials.
Cut funding for live event branding entirely to prioritize the promotional materials.
Remove funds for other campaign elements to maintain the high promotional material budget.

questions.question_text: You are a Sponsorship Coordinator tasked with onboarding a new sponsor for an upcoming gaming tournament. There is no formal onboarding checklist, and the previous coordinator left inconsistent records. What do you do?

options.text: Create a standardized onboarding checklist to ensure the new sponsor’s experience is smooth and professional.
Use the inconsistent records to guide the onboarding process, even if it’s incomplete.
Skip formal onboarding and rely on informal communication with the sponsor.
Delay the onboarding process until you can gather more information.

questions.question_text: You are a Sponsorship Coordinator juggling multiple deadlines for sponsorship deliverables. One client requests additional deliverables that were not agreed upon in the contract. What do you do?

options.text: Politely remind the client of the agreed-upon deliverables outlined in the contract.
Agree to their request and add the additional deliverables without communicating with your team.
Ignore their request and focus on meeting the contracted deliverables.
Request additional funds from the client to cover the new deliverables but delay responding until after the deadline.

questions.question_text: You are a Sponsorship Coordinator invited to speak at a conference attended by industry leaders. After your presentation, multiple sponsors express interest in working with your company. How do you follow up?

options.text: Send personalized emails to each sponsor within 48 hours, highlighting key points from the conversation.
Wait a week before sending a bulk email to all sponsors with general information about your company.
Reach out only to the sponsors whose brands you already know, ignoring smaller potential sponsors.
Send a generic flyer about your sponsorship packages without addressing their specific questions.

questions.question_text: You are a Sponsorship Coordinator seeking new sponsorship opportunities for your company. During a networking event, you meet executives from an industry outside of gaming who express interest in your company. What do you do?

options.text: Explore opportunities with the executives by identifying how partnering could benefit both parties.
Explain that your focus is on gaming sponsors and decline further discussions.
Provide a generic company brochure and walk away without engaging further.
Promise them everything they ask for without verifying alignment with your company's goals.

questions.question_text: You are a Sponsorship Coordinator offered a high-value sponsorship deal. However, the sponsor requests that your company prominently feature messaging that could be considered misleading or against industry ethics. What do you do?

options.text: Decline the messaging request and propose an alternative that aligns with industry ethics.
Agree to feature the messaging as requested to secure the sponsorship deal.
Accept the deal but remove the messaging without informing the sponsor.
Ignore the ethical concerns and pass the decision to your superior.

questions.question_text: You are a Sponsorship Coordinator considering pursuing a certification in sponsorship management to enhance your skills. However, the course requires significant time and financial commitment. What do you do?

options.text: Research how the certification aligns with your career goals and ROI before enrolling.
Enroll immediately without considering the impact on your schedule or finances.
Decide not to pursue the certification and rely on your current skills.
Request that your employer cover the full cost of the course without presenting a justification.

title: Talent Scout - Career Exploration
description: Experience the Talent Scout career through realistic workplace scenarios and decisions
subject: Talent & Scouting

questions.question_text: You are a Talent Scout and notice a conflict brewing between two team members during an online meeting to discuss potential recruits. One team member feels their suggestions are being ignored, while the other insists their candidates are more qualified. What do you do?

options.text: Mediate the discussion, ensuring both team members share their opinions and work towards a consensus.
Side with the team member whose candidates you personally agree with.
End the meeting early and ask both team members to resolve the issue themselves.
Ignore the conflict and continue with the meeting, focusing only on your own suggestions.

questions.question_text: You are a Talent Scout attending an esports tournament in person. A talented player on your shortlist approaches you and asks for feedback on their performance. What do you do?

options.text: Provide constructive feedback, emphasizing their strengths and areas where they can improve to position themselves as a strong recruit.
Tell them they are on your shortlist but avoid providing specific feedback to protect your evaluation process.
Focus only on their weaknesses and suggest they need more work before being considered.
Avoid the conversation entirely to prevent showing bias toward one candidate.

questions.question_text: You are a Talent Scout evaluating a player's performance during an online match. The player's gameplay is impressive, but they are using a gaming setup that does not meet industry standards. This could impact their performance in future high-level competitions. What do you do?

options.text: Note their gameplay performance while documenting the impact of their equipment and consider how they might perform with better gear.
Disqualify the player automatically due to their subpar equipment.
Ignore their equipment and focus only on the gameplay performance.
Recommend the player immediately and assume they will upgrade their equipment later.

questions.question_text: You are a Talent Scout developing a system to evaluate and rank players' skills for your recruitment database. The current system takes too long and is prone to errors. What do you do?

options.text: Research and implement software that automates player performance tracking and analysis.
Continue using the current system, as it has worked in the past despite its inefficiencies.
Create an entirely new system from scratch without consulting your colleagues.
Ignore the system issues and focus on scouting players manually.

questions.question_text: You are negotiating a contract with a promising esports player. They ask for a higher salary than originally offered, claiming they'll bring significant value to the team. However, your budget is already stretched. What do you do?

options.text: Review the player's past performance and assess if their contributions justify negotiating a higher offer within the budget.
Agree to the higher salary to secure the player's talent immediately, even if it exceeds the budget.
Refuse to negotiate and stick firmly to your original offer.
Offer additional non-monetary benefits instead of increasing their salary.

questions.question_text: You are planning your travel budget to attend three esports tournaments in the next quarter. However, your team’s budget has been cut by 20%, and you cannot afford to attend all three events. What do you do?

options.text: Prioritize the tournaments based on the quality of players attending and potential recruiting opportunities.
Attend the nearest tournaments to save on travel costs, regardless of their importance.
Cancel all travel plans and rely solely on online scouting tools.
Ask the company to increase your budget despite the cut.

questions.question_text: You are a Talent Scout and need to create a structured process to track new player inquiries efficiently. Right now, requests are coming in through emails, social media, and direct messages, which is overwhelming. What do you do?

options.text: Set up a centralized form and database for players to submit inquiries, allowing you to manage information systematically.
Focus on responding to inquiries in the order they arrive, even if it’s chaotic.
Hire an intern to manage the influx of inquiries.
Ignore inquiries from social media since they’re less professional.

questions.question_text: You are juggling multiple tasks, including attending online matches, preparing scouting reports, and scheduling interviews with players. A manager just requested a detailed report on one player within the next hour. What do you do?

options.text: Pause your current tasks and focus on completing the player report as requested by the manager.
Continue multitasking to meet all your deadlines at once.
Ignore the manager’s request and finish your current tasks first.
Request an extension on all your tasks to avoid feeling overwhelmed.

questions.question_text: You are a Talent Scout at a gaming convention and meet a representative from a major esports organization. They express interest in collaborating with your team. What do you do?

options.text: Exchange contact information and follow up with them after the event to discuss potential partnerships.
Politely decline their offer to collaborate, as you already have many players to scout.
Ask them to email your manager directly for further discussions.
Immediately commit to a partnership without consulting your team or manager.

questions.question_text: You are a Talent Scout and have been invited to participate in a podcast on esports recruitment. This could help build your reputation in the industry, but it conflicts with a player evaluation session you’re scheduled to attend. What do you do?

options.text: Reschedule the player evaluation session and use the podcast opportunity to grow your professional network.
Skip the podcast to ensure you don’t miss the player evaluation session.
Decline the podcast invitation, as it’s not directly related to scouting talent.
Attempt to participate in the podcast and attend the player evaluation session at the same time.

questions.question_text: You are a Talent Scout and discover that a player you’re considering for recruitment has been involved in cheating allegations in the past. No formal action was taken, but there is some evidence that suggests they may have cheated. What do you do?

options.text: Investigate the player’s past thoroughly and discuss the allegations with them directly before making a decision.
Ignore the allegations since they were never formally acted upon.
