Include the visual effects at your own expense to maintain a good relationship with the client.
Refuse to add the visual effects and proceed without notifying the client.
Agree to the changes and exceed the budget, hoping to resolve it later.

questions.question_text: You are a Videographer negotiating your fee with a small gaming startup that has a limited budget. They ask for a discount in exchange for a long-term contract. What do you do?

options.text: Offer a slight discount while maintaining terms that ensure a fair rate for the long-term contract.
Agree to a heavily discounted rate to secure the contract.
Refuse the discount and insist on your standard rate.
Negotiate multiple free projects upfront in exchange for exposure.

questions.question_text: You are a Videographer editing a gaming team’s promotional video. The client insists on daily updates, but this disrupts your regular editing workflow. What do you do?

options.text: Set clear expectations with the client on realistic update frequencies to balance productivity.
Agree to provide daily updates, even if it compromises the quality of your work.
Ignore their request and deliver the final product without consulting them further.
Ask for additional time for the project but avoid discussing their request for updates.

questions.question_text: You are a Videographer working on a montage tape for a gaming competition. The deadline is tomorrow, but you find that some clips need re-editing for smoother transitions. What do you do?

options.text: Prioritize the most critical edits and work efficiently to meet the deadline.
Delay the delivery to ensure every clip is perfectly edited.
Submit the montage tape as is without attempting any changes.
Request an extension from the client without providing specific reasons.

questions.question_text: You are a Videographer attending a large gaming event. Between shoots, you meet representatives from a major esports organization interested in your work. What do you do?

options.text: Engage in a casual but professional conversation and share your portfolio with them.
Ignore them since you're focused on your current project and don’t want distractions.
Offer to work for them immediately and abandon your current client.
Ask them to email you instead of discussing anything at the event.

questions.question_text: You are a Videographer looking to grow your career. A gaming team client loves your work and asks for exclusivity, but you’re unsure if this will limit future opportunities. What do you do?

options.text: Negotiate terms that allow you to work for other clients while maintaining a strong partnership.
Agree to exclusivity to secure steady income without considering long-term impacts.
Decline the offer immediately without exploring potential benefits of exclusivity.
Accept the exclusivity proposal and plan to secretly take on additional clients anyway.

questions.question_text: You are a Videographer deciding whether to invest in a new 4K camera or spend money on advanced editing software. Your budget allows only one for now. What do you do?

options.text: Invest in the editing software to enhance your current equipment and wait for future funds to purchase the camera.
Buy the 4K camera and rely on existing editing software that lacks advanced features.
Spend the budget on a less expensive camera and lower-quality editing software to get both.
Postpone both purchases and continue using outdated equipment until your next payment comes in.

questions.question_text: You are a Videographer considering online certification in advanced cinematography techniques that could boost your reputation. The certification is costly and time-consuming. What do you do?

options.text: Invest in the certification to develop your skills and attract high-paying clients in the future.
Avoid the certification and focus solely on your current gigs.
Take the certification but minimize effort to save time for other projects.
Find a free online course instead, even if it lacks credibility in the industry.
